title: Meg you later....NOT!
text: When you go to the cinema, please check your brain with the staff. If you took it with you, you'd have plenty to question. The cheese fest smells like 10 day-old pizza. It's that bad. I couldn't keep up because I was too busy wondering why the previous scene actually made it in the movie and not on the cutting room floor.Light-weight acting, 1980's cgi, irritating characters. I felt nothing but boredom!The inside jokes seemed to be funny for the characters but not for the audience. We are outsiders, so this type of humour falls flat on us. Bad idea!Going through all of the action, water based mainly, not one character got wet! Did I miss something, was it a special ocean that wasn't wet? I just mainly got lost on wondering these type of things and snoozed the rest of the movie. It's bad, it doesn't deliver, it's boring. A Meg you later...NOT!

title: Meg, then Meg 2, hopefully in the near future, Meg Three-wheheeeeeey, LOVED IT!
text:
To those that rate this film 2 or 3 out of 10, I think you picked the wrong film for your supposed intellect. What's you expecting to watch War and Peace, The Great Expectations, or Dull and Dullenheimer?In future, please review movies that meet your intellect, and leave the escapism reviews to us brainless zombeavers!Without giving too much away, this film is basically Jason Statham once again having a close-up and personal face-off against histories biggest shark(s), and giving it his all, in a slightly hammed up way, (this kid CAN do comedy) whilst being superbly supported by a fantastic cast that includes, Jing Wu, Fear The Walking Dead's Chris Curtis, teen actress, Sophia Cai, and many others, including the main bad guy, and piece of s*** from Rambo: Last Blood, Sergio Peris-Mencheta, who, once again revels in that type of role, and also adds unexpected crying.What a big and bad baby?And, that finally brings me back to the BIG money movie that 'stole' the idea, or rather, paid homage to some Asylum Pictures films, and made them even more watchable and enjoyable, because The Meg movies 'franchise' seems to be following a trend, in my eyes, and after watching The Meg 2, it could, and quite satisfyingly go.un a multi-verse of directions...
... Statham v a GIANT SHARK, a GIANT APE, and GIANT LIZARD, or having Jason Statham pilot the Mecha-lodon against the historical behemoth, or even leading the Expendabl5's team against the new global warlords?If you leave your brains in the fruit bowl, along with you're car keys, (you sly dogs), and just sit back and watch two hours of a fantastically enjoyable romp.Oh, and by the way, if I didn't already say it, what a fantastic piece of clever mindlessness from Ben Wheatley?MORE,MORE, MORE, please!

title: Megaladonmania
text: It was fun to watch in the cinema. But this isn't a Megalodon movie. Under the Sea is a movie about smuggling. Although it is Meg 2, we see Megaladon towards the end of the movie. This spoiled the fun of the movie. Megaladon scenes were very few. It was good as an action, but the fight scenes were overexposed. Especially Jason Statham. Cgi was sometimes good, sometimes very bad. It was fun to watch as a popcorn movie. There are some scenes, i fell asleep... Although I enjoyed watching it in the cinema in general, I think it's a bad movie. I think it would be better if there were more Megaladon scenes, if it was a bit of a scientific movie rather than an action movie. But this movie is also a book adaptation.

title: What was good about the first is not present in the second
text: Cool kill scenes and funny moments made thr first meg entertaining to watch and allowed the viewer to step back and forget about life for a while while ignoring why the first film was not a good film but still worth seeing.This is the opposite of that.This film is so clearly made for China it's appalling, every good guy is asian, every bad guy is white or hispanic while also spending time talking about the Chinese governments commitment to the environment. There is no cool or ridiculous action except maybe the last 10 minutes, the "comedy" does not land at all, the characters are not even remotely enjoyable. I cannot recommend spending time watching this film even if it were for charity.

title: Disappointing
text: The trailer looked great.I was really pumped to see the sequel.And what a letdown,Stupid characters, a main character with a thick accent, dumb scenes, dumb plot, too much unnecessary 'humor'.The saving grace was the last 20 minutes or so. I enjoyed that. The rest of it was just bad.If you liked the first one, worth seeing for the shark action in the last 20. Otherwise, don't bother. Jaws it definitely is not!But if they make another, I'd go see. Always loved shark movies. Even the bad ones.And Jason is always the coolest dude on the planet, worth it to see him in practically anything.

title: How wacky is Meg 2:The Trench ?
text:
IN A NUTSHELL:This sequel to the summer blockbuster The Meg features a research team that encounters multiple threats while exploring the oceanic trench. Add in environmental messaging about evil mining operations and humorous conversations about parenting, and you get a green sequel that doesn't have the same bit as the first film.The film was directed by Ben Wheatly. Writing credits go to Jon Hoeber, Erich Hoeber, and Dean Georgaris.THINGS I LIKED:If you like Jason Statham as I do, you'll get a kick out of this movie. He also worked as one of the Executive Producers of the film. He's great a comedy, drama, and, of course, action. If you liked the first Meg movie, this is more of the same schtick...and a lot of fun.Other cast members include Jing Wu, Shuya Sophia Cai, Page Kennedy, Sergio Peris-Mencheta, Sienna Guillory, Cliff Curtis, and Skyler Samuels. Everyone does a great job.Like the first Meg movie, there is a large Chinese influence. I've been to China many times on business trips and love the country and its people. One of my sons even married a lovely girl from Hong Kong! I now have a half-Chinese grandson who is ridiculously adorable.Impressive set pieces.For a creature feature, we see plenty of crazy action.The movie, thankfully, doesn't take itself too seriously. The trailer clearly showed us this would be a goofy, summer, popcorn movie.If you enjoy watching mean-spirited, stupid people die, this film is for you.Some of the VFX are great, while others aren't so great.The scenarios are ridiculous, but no one will ever say this movie isn't creative!In addition to an even bigger Meg, than we saw in the first film, we see sharks, more Megs, and a bunch of creepy, crawly monsters that fight dirty.THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE:You can't fault people for their heavy Chinese accents, yet some people probably will.Apparently, Page Kennedy, one of the actors in the film who happily collected his paycheck stated, "This is some dumb a$$ shiX. Mark my words."
British director Ben Wheatley is known for his horror movies such as Free Fire, In The Earth, and Kill List. Fans of the horror genre are disappointed that this movie doesn't have enough blood and gore. I'm totally fine without all of that!Sometimes, it's hard to tell exactly what's happening in the dark scenes and when creatures are all over the place attacking humans.I hate shaky cam.It's outlandish.The villains are easily unlikeable and just silly.TIPS FOR PARENTS:In the first scene, we see dangerous, prehistoric creatures fight and devour each other.Lots of destruction.People are in perilous situations
A lot of people die.People violently fight other people and creatures with various weapons.Blood and gore.

title: Sharknado with somewhat better graphics
text:
This is exactly why movies with giant animals have such a bad rep...it's almost offensively bad.Ok, it's a bit weird to except realistic behavior if you're talking about a movie with Megalodon in it BUT what about common logic, physics and biology?First of all..animals that live in the deep seas can't just go up to the surface, they would literally implode, let's get that straightSharks have skin like sandpaper..you can't just pet them with your bare hands while they pass you.Only cause something is big, it doesn't mean it's automatically evil. It makes no sense at all for a giant shark to literally hunt for humans..that's literally the same as if you would go out of your way to hunt down just one single pea...and also, sharks don't eat boats or bridges. Sharks don't smash their heads against armored glass just to eat one single human...
Krakens won't try to take down helicopters..cause why would they...The sharks were only like a sidekick..nobody really cared or was stunned or anything that normal human beings would feel..especially if it's 'the biggest shark they ever came across'.The entire movie is about humans and their terrible...terrible TERRIBLE wannabe, cringy one liners and 'jokes'. The characters are offensively flat and an absolute clich√®.Instead of making washed up, cookie cutter action movies, they could have donated the money for better purpose...

title: Forget Barbenheimer it's Shark Week Baby
text: Forget Barbenheimer it's Shark Week Baby! From Ben Wheatley (Yep the director of Kill List and A Field in England, so beloved by Golk Horror aficionados) comes a sequel to one of the greatest Guilty Pleasure movies of all time, 2018's The Meg.The first movie was a lean mean killing machine that delighted audiences with some tightly directed action and monster munching mayhem, and Wheatley doesn't try to fix what was never broken with his sequel. What he does do is take the same basic premise and rum the gauntlet with it, and boy does he have some fun doing so. You know this guy grew up watching movies like Warlords of Atlantis The Land That Time Forgot, and At The Earth's Core from the colourful sub aqua world created at the foot of the deep sea trench. You know he read 2000 AD comic from the futuristic gadgetry and deep sea diving suits. You know he watched Jaws 2 on TV more times than anyone had a right to as did we all), hell they even reference that much maligned (by some) movie with JD's poison tip bullets.Will the Meg 2 win any awards? No. But go into it knowing what to expect and have a movie watching blast,then enjoy the negative reviews of people moaning that it lacks any realism.

title: Hungry for money, not people.
text: Nowhere near as camp & whimsically nonsensical as it should've been.Hollywood takes Ben Wheatley (an indie / auteur director I've long admired, whose nich√©, very wry, quintessentially British comedy is usually derived from mocking the knowingly self-aware ridiculousness of his own absurd concepts) & mercilessly sanitises his style for maximum appeal... Thus, appealing to nobody.He's silly, basically. Let him be silly.On the one hand, I totally understand the need to cater to a broader clientele (especially with productions burdened by a larger price tag - so as to recoup the hefty budgets given, turn a profit & increase the value of share holder's stock etc. Capitalism, baby) & consequently, why executives put so much pressure on creators to bend their visions, ever so slightly (during all stages of development; appeasing those who dare not wish to see studios taking risks with their money - preferring safe investments, subsidised with cash from their pockets)... But we also mustn't forget that filmmaking is - after all - an art form (constantly fraught with risk - which has to be taken for any possibility of thriving) & for example, if one commissions a piece of artwork from a particular person (renowned for possessing a certain, signature style of which they're known for), then in theory, one must also accept that they should be permitted the creative freedom to express themselves authentically (in that way), without corporate shills constantly breathing down their necks with disapproval.Therefore, we can all agree (?) for instance, it would be clearly illogical to purchase an iconic piece by Rembrandt & then berate the painting for not emulating the works of Picasso; they're two entirely different entities, whose outlooks were defined by separate lifestyles & thus, bore very individualistic fruit - in terms of how they captured perceptions of reality (& communicated them) at the time.The efficacy of what was conjured will forever remain subjective (in stirring emotions or articulating the point apparently intended); after all, art is meant to provoke debate & stimulate discussion... Nevertheless, both are valid in their own right & (not to labour a point) if one specific approach is selected, then it should be respected, specifically.The same can be said here; so afraid of failure are those behind the scenes, their inability to allow originality, experimentalism & recalcitrance (deviating little from the formulaic, cut & paste template used for a usual blockbuster) stymies the project's chances of succeeding on its own terms - ironically bringing about the very outcome sought to be avoided; a bitter-sweet, self-fulfilling prophecy, as it were & a mistake repeated again & again & again, noticeably at Warner Bros.Subsequently, Ben Wheatley's held back by a visible obligation to be what he's wanted to be (by others in higher positions of power around him), not who he actually is, himself. Granted, his identity occasionally shines through the banality of the generic blockbuster filmmaking he's consigned to undertake - & I appreciated those glimmers, irrespective of how few & far between they seemed... But those fleeting moments of brilliance aren't enough to compensate for the rest of it, unfortunately.Hence, I left the cinema, dissatisfied.

title: Absolute blast
text:
We watched it in 3D. Sadly the screen was quite small. The opening sequence was pretty great and some incredible scenery shots were beautiful but ultimately it didn't need to be seen in 3D unfortunately..
I will say, on its own two feet, this film was great. It did this in a completely unexpected way to me. From the trailers I was all geared up for ridiculousness just this side of Sharknado, and I was happy with that!!However! It turned out to be so much more. I don't mean to say this movie rips off anything. I'd only say parts were familiar simply because they came before. The movie itself retains it's uniqueness.For me it belongs alongside Leviathan, Jurassic Park, Alien (or maybe Aliens), Pitch Black, Deep Rising and of course Jaws.It manages to be about the people not the megs. Not bigger more glorious deaths. Though it has those.Like the aforementioned films it draws you in and makes you care. So the 'beat the clock' moments are really intense... And not everyone works out for the heroes. In fact when one or two does, you get comfortable and then BAM!, one doesn't. But not in a gimmicky way. It really works. I was never taken out of the story.Also, like the aforementioned movies, the humor is natural. Not necessarily realistic every time I suppose but it never undermined the moment or the movie
The men made mistakes but were strong, competent, take charge and caring characters.The women were strong competent characters who were human and made mistakes.I... REALLY enjoyed this film. Definitely going to be a purchase. I'm ready for a 3rd. I genuinely don't believe it can be better than this one, but that's ok.

title: might be better than the first!
text: Meg 2: The Trench very well might be better than the first! I think the key, and I truly believe this of any sequel is the return of characters from the previous film, especially using the same actors!I believe 4 characters return in this one, and Pippin the dog (though I'm not certain that it is indeed the same dog...)!The beginning of the film, with the food chain sequence is excellent, as is the opening sequence with Jonas as a "green James Bond"! Lots of action mixed with a bit more humor, and of course, quite a lot of megladons! Definitely worth seeing on its opening weekend!On the negative side, it definitely is too long and could have used a bit of story editing. Also, some of the humor gets a little bit too silly. But all-in-all, well worth watching in the theater!

title: Worse movie I ever saw
text: Got a day off, left kids for the first time with nanny, went at the cinema with my partner. Completely dissapointed, no sense in the movie at all, just chaos. Thought Jason Statham has good roles in the popular movies but no...I gave a star because it wasnt 0 stars on the chart. Movie for teenagers not for adults. Watched in 3D, is not colourful is just dark greyish colours on the screen. Not a lot of 3D scenes. Some of them was nice but nothing more. I wouldnt recomment to watch it to anyone, just waste of time and money, if you decide to go cinema. The best thing abouth the movie was popcorn and cola (no offence).

title: Writing this in the theater
text: This movie is so bad I had to review it during the film. I knew it would be bad but it's worse then expected.I really do t have anything else to say but it's making me right more so I guess I'll justsay some more bad scenes l. One part brags about an influencer having 400 likes and then less then 5 minutes later with no reason no cellphone work and landlines somehow are not working too. Some how sharks did this I guess. Everyone should have does hundreds of tike, I wish I was exaggerating but I'm not.Jetskies survive ridiculousness. Stole a scene from Jaws 4 where a shark is impaled but it is somehow still worse then that terrible movie.Anyone eating this movie highly either is a part of the company or has not appreciation for good movies.

title: Yawn.....Zzzzzzzz.
text: Let me preface this with, I love the big set piece, dumb, sci-fi action movies and I love Statham. Until I saw this. 3/4 of the way through I turned the channel as the story and motivations fir the characters was beyond absurd! Only watch thus if you are tied down and you cannot get the channel that teaches you how to use your remote control for cable. Peeeeeyew!The plot is stupid and the story meandered all over the place. If you have a choice watch anything else. This "movie" should only be shown to the criminally insane as punishment. However, since we have a law against cruel and unusual punishment.... I would recommend this to no one!!!

title: A fun Goofy Movie!, that has interesting ideas, and looks impressive
text: Movie was a good dumb fun film. Which is what it was meant to be, and it doesn't fail to deliver on that part. And this is a rear sequal that improves upon the first. The Action is cranked up, the tension is cranked up, and so is the humouras characters, goofy as anything no less. But believe it or not, this movie has more good then bad. Starting of with the Characters.Characters,They are way more goofy this time, and sometimes it's a good thing, sometimes it's not. Like for example, when an army of soldiers try to attack them, the scene has some tension but also uses humour as a destraction, this is a good thing as they use a clever technique to get out of the situation. And for me it worked. However, this is a bad thing at times as there's not enough Character development here. To make you route for the characters, so it's kind of difficult. And if your looking for a movie with less goofy characters and a better overall story, then just watch Jaws or Deep Blue sea. The new auditions here are fine, but in execution they don't work. And large proportions of that is down to the lack of development and traits they may or could have sustained throughout some of the movie, but sadly it lacks here. And there also here for comic relief, atleast it felt like that. So it sort of looses it's tension In that respect, again it does suit (no pun intended) works with the overall story/Movie. Now onto the Plot.Plot,Has an interesting start, which is on the trailer. But it's got some vastly good ideas, because it's got Dinosaurs, and time sequence that takes place 65M years before. And the Dinosaur sequence starts of with tension, and keeps it up. And then the T-Rex comes, and is loud and let's out a gasply terrifying roar. And now that's the moment the tension drops for the suspenseful part. And is such a beutiful scene, and that's when the Credits roll up and we are now greeted with the present day, and it all comes naturally, it's not all in your face, and there's no Music, which is a good thing, for the same reason. It's a quick action-Packed start, still manages to not be to overbearing and in your face, which will keep you away from possible neusia, as it's not over stuffed.Talking about the present day, as the small Dinosaurs, and the 2 other Megs has come out of the Trench. The team, in overly equipped armour built suites go to investigate the Mariana trench. And are conflicted with facing the biggest Meg. Which does lack tension, granted the scene is amusing and entertaining. But the armour suites detract from what the original had, and that was having no protection, and only a smart and clever way to figure out how to get out of it. And then the second act takes place. On a cruise ship. Where they are captured by the Army. But break free easily, and have a clever way to get out. No Spoilers. And that's when the third act takes place on an island. The Name of the island is so dumb, its hillarious. But one thing the movie does well is managing to balance out the lighter and darker tones, which majority of the time works well respectfully, probably 85%. As I said it does lack some development and can lack the tension. But mostly does work. Now Moving onto the Action.Action/Effects,The Colours on the movie is a delight, so much colour and attention to detail is quite incredible really. The slick tone really elevates the action sequences. And the Dinosaurs really are well designed, lots of detail and are well integrated with the plot, and actually have some great moments, like when they get to take down the greedy Army men. Those scenes were well shot, well paced, and had the tension to keep it interesting. The Characters don't have much personality, and are thin of any traits, but do have some moments to shine. Like when Octopus shows up, and Mi Ling is trapped, one of the team members saves her. Statham shows us a clever side and has to think of interesting ways to kill of the Megladons. And the tension and the humour which can get annoying is also cranked up in the final act.The end scene wasn't very good, it felt rushed. And didn't end in a good place, but overall it's a Fun film that gets WAY to much hate. It's meant to be dumb, and it's meant to be fun. And it is. And it doesn't fail to Entertain, which is it's main focus and job. That offers a few laughs here and there. Now time for my Verdict.Verdict,6.5/10 Fairly good. Recency Bias when I watched the first one I put 7, but I think overtime it's a 6.Meg=6/10, Meg 2:The Trench 6.5/10Overall rating for the sequal=12.5/20 NOT Bad!

title: 'Meg 2: The Trench' Review - A Wild Ride of Dumb Fun
text: When it comes to movies, sometimes all we need is some good old dumb fun, and "Meg 2: The Trench" delivers just that!While it may not be an epic or extraordinary film with jaw-dropping moments, it sure knows how to entertain without taking itself too seriously.The movie is filled with over-the-top creatures and scenarios.Jonah has transformed into an eco-warrior, taking on a role similar to Jason Statham's, running around beating up the bad guys. He's essentially an overly aggressive Captain Planet, making for a hilarious and action-packed storyline.Most of the crew from the first movie returns, adding to the familiar and enjoyable atmosphere."Meg 2: The Trench" embraces its status as a fan movie set in the deep seas, offering a thrilling ride packed with non-stop action that keeps you engaged throughout.While it may not aim for greatness, the film delivers on its promise of entertainment.It's not concerned about scientific accuracy or complex plots, but rather focuses on providing pure joy for shark movie enthusiasts and fans of Jason Statham's action style.The supporting cast may not steal the show, and the CGI might not be top-notch, but the movie's fun factor outweighs any minor flaws."Meg 2: The Trench" is a rollercoaster ride that captivates from start to finish, leaving no room for serious analysis or nitpicking.If you're a Jason Statham fan or love shark movies, this film will undoubtedly satisfy your craving for action & thrill.Prepare for an exhilarating two-hour joyride filled with pure, unadulterated bonkers movie-making that will keep you entertained - an experience that's all about good vibes.

title: Well, it's better than the first
text: Jason Statham versus CGI sharks sounded good on paper some where. Then again it sounded good again but multiple fake sharks but throw in an octopus and some kimodo dragon thingys.While the first wasn't a masterpiece by any means it did work as popcorn summer flick who like Jason Statham.This time around there's some bad guys trying to sabotage the operation of technological suits and a captive meg. The baddies are the work of an inside job and add the ocean's trench and you can see where this is headed. Good thing they got Jason to save the day because he's pretty much the last action hero in movies today.Still, it wasn't bad and I did enjoy the action packed third act. Just don't walk in expecting a masterpiece but it's better than the first one.

title: A MUST SEE MOVIE IN 4DX & 3D
text: If you saw this movie in regular format screens and then complain you have absolutely no vote nor room for complaints. This movie is absolutely AWESOME in 3D alongside with all the effects of a quality 4DX cinema experience. I am a fan of seeing movies in the highest quality as possible for sound, image, 3D and special effects, thus this MARVEL of movie delights every sense and takes advantage of all 4DX technology to the maximum for an absolutely inmersive experience, thank you guys for making such an epic jewel for this movie in 4DX and can't wait to see the third installment. I definitely enjoyed this second installment.

title: Worth seeing just for the deep sea exploration
text: I enjoyed this film mainly for the technology, adventure / submersion, and action sequences.You don't get enough deep sea films despite their potential with it being the last unexplored location on Earth.Good points: engaging from start to finish, deep sea imagery, deep sea subs / suits, some funny moments, dinosaur scenes, megalodon scenes, action, underwater base discovery.Bad points: there was one glaring plot hole with a helicopter that I noticed, the humour wasn't great - copying the black guy-turned-clown from Fast and Furious idea, the CGI of the initial dinosaur scene was atrocious, and finally I think they could've spent more time with the deep sea exploration as it's so rarely done. Really, they may have tried to put too much in one film, or not made it long enough in my opinion.It's an easy film to watch and turn off your mind; I would ignore the negative reviewers if you just want to use your imagination. The plot holes are rather insignificant.

title: Not what expected
text: Me and my friends were exited for this movie, but left with disappointment. There was just too much going on, especially at the end. So many different scenes of different action happening. First it was the sharks they were fighting against, at the same time the people who want them dead, the land animals and then a frickin octopus! I was left with rolling my eyes through half of the movie - it was predictable and too much.There weren't any plotwists, only one which was obvious. It felt like there were 15 different producers who added their ideas in one movie. There's honestly not much to say but by far the most boring action movie.

title: Saved by the third act just about
text: Meg 2: The Trench borrows way too much from Jurassic World: Dominion especially with a focus on boring, Meg free human on human action for the majority of the run time but any film that has Jason Statham on a jet ski with explosive harpoons fighting a prehistoric Shark isn't all bad.Statham himself remains the ideal lead to carry this but Jonas feels like any other Statham performance now and Jonas wasn't that unique to begin with. One of the few smart decisions this film makes is to really focus on his relationship with Shuya Sophia Cai which remains really endearing.Despite his previous work Ben Wheatley has made a Meg sequel more voiceless and bloodless than the original. He also struggles with the huge leap in budget from his usual work with choppy action and underwater sequences where it's hard to tell who's still alive.On the other hand, his film is more knowingly stupid than its predecessor and the prehistoric opening gets it started on the right foot. There's a few knowing needle drops that work and the third act essentially saves the film from being a truly awful missed opportunity.

title: MEG 2 The Trash
text: Five minutes in, my wife and I looked at each other and I apologized for choosing this awful waste of time instead of another movie she wanted to see. The acting is horrendous and at times I had the feeling that some of the actor/actresses voices were dubbed. The script, science and CGI gives you silly willies. Nothing in this movie makes sense and it's been a long time since I wanted to walk out of the cinema in disgust. Popcorn was great so what was the only reason. Please don't waste time and money on this nonsense. I knew right from the start this was going to be bad when I saw the "studios" that were behind this. Thanks for nothing.

title: If you like shark movies...
text: This movie is made well, I like the action and the story line. Usually when you have seen one shark movie it seems you have seen them all, it seems the plots are all the same, however, this movie has better storyline, good action, and great suspense.I would recommend seeing this on a big screen theaters as oppose to waiting to see it on your home entertainment system.The big screen will gives you a better immersive view of all the great scenery in the movie.The special effects are fantastically done.You will not be board watching this thriller.Overall, this is a great movie for all ages.

title: So bad, it's funny!
text: I don't know what I was thinking paying to see this movie. The first Meg was bad but at least it gave the sense of awe and jeopardy. This latest installment is beyond silly. It is unintentionally hilarious in places and the CGI is awesome, but somewhat overused.Jason Statham and Cliff Curtis are playing the "good guys" roles with too much intensity and complete lack of situational awareness. It's like they really think they're in an awesome monster movie like Godzilla or Cloverfield. The rest of the cast are OK for the most part, although they haven't done their careers any service. It's basically a B movie made with modern technology.

title: Much worse than first one. Don't believe the hype!
text: Save your time & money of watching this c*ap.It so stupid plot, stupid directing, lame acting. Studio and producers with movie director just bombed movie with big budget and special effects and took some advertising followed by media/social media hype. So much stupidity in this move with it's plot like whole is written by 10 year old kid... I will save my time and my nerves so not go in the details what is wrong, because EVERYTHING IS WRONG WITH THE SCRIPT AND WITH THE DIRECTING. Lame characters (wrote) reactions & lame acting... Can't figure it out box office achievement.I wish my time and my annoying back.

title: Why? Why? Why?
text: When it comes to worst sequels of all time... The exorcist 2, The Howling 2, Rob Zombies Halloween 2, David Gordon Greens Halloween Ends, The Meg 2 stands head and shoulders above them all. Case in point.. one character from The Meg movie returns and he has learnt martial arts and carries around a backpack with weapons so he stands a chance against a 70 foot Meg... he learnt martial arts to take on a Meg.... did anyone in the studio read The trench? After watching this atrocious movie.. it seems not.This movie deserves an award for being worse in every conceivable way to the first movie. I can't unwatch what I saw and that will haunt me forever. Avoid at all costs.

title: Even Jason Statham can't save an idiotic script
text: Full disclosure: I tried getting through this twice but could not.If this is what AI screenwriting is gonna be like, then I'm pretty comfortable in the belief that Hollywood screenwriters are fine. Sadly, IMDB suggests it took four humams to compose this absolutely unlistenable script. Is it possible AI could outwrite humans? Meg 2 makes a solid case for yes.The best scenes are the ones with no or little dialogue, which is the most consistently cringe-worthy I've seen outside of the low-budget dregs of Redbox.My hat is off to anyone whose love of the Statham powered them through this movie. Mine met its limit.

title: I pretended I was Jason Statham on the way home
text: It's not going to win an Oscar. Despite this it is great fun. Everything crazy about the sea is shoved into this film. It's like a small kid who makes a cake and sticks every conceivable decoration on it. As I drove home from the cinema with my daughter, I flew over a speed hump in the road and for a moment I thought I was Jason Statham riding a wave on a jet ski about to harpoon a Meg. Such an intense experience.My daughter: 'Absolutely bonkers. Felt like 2 films cobbled together, but I enjoyed every second. I can testify that my Dad drove too fast over a speed bump. Not pleasant. Worth watching.'

title: No More, Please
text: This movie couldn't decide what it was, a thriller or a (terrible) comedy. It's almost like they changed scripts and directors midway through.Positives: The cast, they were actually pretty good... but playing roles modeled after (lame) cartoon characters. The CGI and the cinematography were quite good. However, that's the end of the good things about Meg 2.Only a mathematicians of Pythagoras' caliber could keep count of the number of last-second-escapes crammed into this flick. It was embarrassing. After the first few, one could sense the trend, and a grim sense of foreboding descends on the viewer.But it gets far worse as the film progresses. At the end it comes across as a slapstick fest.I could say more, but be forewarned. If you liked the first film, do not -- do not -- assume that this one will entertain you in remotely the same manner.

title: Lots of action, fun day at the movies
text: It's entertaining and action packed. Loved the movie and laughed and jumped often. The movie features, a lot of CGI, which is realistic looking, especially when the shark is cut into the water. Space. The start of the movie was very interesting and similar to Jurassic Park. The additional creatures featured in the film, gave some diversity to the oversized, killing machines and their ability to inflict digestive justice on the bad guys. Once again, Little Pippen, the dog was featured and was fighting monsters alongside the heroes of the film. I would recommend this for kids above 10 as it is a lot of fun, but does have some semi violent scenes.

title: Below the Average
text: Below the average. Forget about the story even the visual effects of creatures were not good. Few movies made a decade ago where so good in vfx compared to this. Could have been much better with this kinda budget.Below the average. Forget about the story even the visual effects of creatures were not good. Few movies made a decade ago where so good in vfx compared to this. Could have been much better with this kinda budget.Very below the average. Forget about the story even the visual effects of creatures were not good. Few movies made a decade ago where so good in vfx compared to this. Could have been much better with this kinda budget.

title: It's the only option
text: The Meg 2 delves into the realms of the preposterous and might just be the most enjoyable 'bad' movie ever. It's as if it candidly asks viewers to leave any notion of logic and disbelief at the door, promising in return a barrage of unapologetic, over-the-top shark mayhem. Statham, ever the action hero, stands toe-to-fin with a prehistoric behemoth in scenes that oscillate between tense and laugh-out-loud. There's a joy in watching something that doesn't pretend to be anything other than what it is: a glorious, brain-off, popcorn muncher of a flick. It has it all, sharks, dinosaurs, submersible's, betrayal, revenge, man bags and so so much more!

title: It's a meg, you're a snack
text: No pun intended - actually considering the size of the shark (it still is considered a shark right? As you can tell I am not too familiar in the world of animals - especially the prehistoric ones) ... you might not even be a snack (too small/little and all that).That all being said, the movie is more or less what you would expect it to be. What was surprising from the get go (at least for me): reading the name of the director! Ben Wheatley is not really known for big budget movies - quite the opposite is true for him (see Field of England, Sightseers and so forth) ... but him tipping his toe in this new unfamiliar territory (knowing full well there is no Meg in there of course .. although ...) is quite the treat.You don't even have to have seen the first one to enjoy this one. Although you will get a few inside jokes and some character development ... the movie is quite predictable - though I did not mind or felt that the eco message was too much. This is what you would expect a movie like this to be ... it hits all the right notes ... just ride the wave ... do it like Statham (does anyone stand a chance against him?)

title: Meg short for meg-a waste of ur time, life and whole existence
text: Although this review could be used for the first movie due to it being so inaccurate, since this movie was tremendously worse I'm going to put this review here. I love how scientifically accurate this movie is, megalodons that are known to be extinct because the water temperatures got too cold it for it too survive, so what did this movie do? Put the meg in an underwater sea cloud below the Mariana Trench, the Meg would not have been able to survive temperatures below 12 degrees Celsius so what a good idea it would be to put this prehistoric shark below the coldest part of the ocean. The trench can reach temperatures from 4 - 1 degrees Celsius which the Meg wouldn't be able to survive already but to put it underneath this, therefore the water being colder, why would the megaladon be living in the coldest part of the sea? And the only thing preventing it from coming to warmer water is a thin sea cloud that it only escaped from once a ship went through it.

title: Definitely Better Than The First One
text: I am beginning to think that many of these YouTube movie reviewers haven't actually seen this film and think because they do a negative review it will get more views for their channel. The question of course is what qualifies them to do reviews in the first place and nine times out of ten its nothing. They do not seem to be a fan of cinema but they want to be celebs in their own right by pushing out unqualified reviews or wasting peoples time with "reaction" videos. So far so dumb.One such reviewer couple, male and female claimed that nothing happens in the first hour. They must have fallen asleep as we have deaths, explosions, chases and punch ups, all within the first few mins and it doesn't let up. This couple then claimed that the movie should have been like the closing action sequence all the way through the movie because "that is what they came for". Such a clueless viewpoint just shows the mentality of these YouTube reviewers. It seems some people expected Jason to be punching a giant CGI shark for two hours. Oh dear. The other complaint doing the round is there are no sharks until the final act, no true either, nor is it true that if you have seen the trailer you have seen all of the action scenes. Make me think these reviewers are simply repeating each others lies about this. The fact is there is more action and better story in this film, while the previous one was more like Jaws, this is its own movie. And Ben Wheatleys' background in horror is self evident because what this movie has over the previous one are far more satisfying death scenes. Just about everyone and everything that dies does so in a manner that brings a warm glow.Its obvious that this is doing well at the box office through word of mouth, just goes to show that these YouTube characters seem to be screaming into the void. Very few people are listening to their opinions and those that do seem to have them over ridden by people they know who have seen this. I would recommend this as a big screen experience, the first one did what it said on the tin, this time you are gonna need a bigger tin to fit it all in.

title: I can honestly say I was thrilled.
text: I will honestly give this a 6 review because it's really not that bad of a movie. The CGI was a little disappointing when it came to landscape and scenery in the beginning of the movie, showed a little bit laziness or penny pinching to this but it didn't really take away that much from the whole movie in general. It wasn't the best but to be fair the acting, plot and story was not only excellently done, it was really intriguing and most importantly, enjoyable. The actors we have seen in other things, worked well together and even the little girl was amazing. I can honestly say I was thrilled to see this film and can't wait for the 2nd one.

title: A MEGa Mashup of Movie Genres In One Absurdly Fun Package
text:
LIKES:Fast Fun:
-I went in knowing what this movie was going to be and I wasn't disappointed that the pace of the film was on point.-Pedal to the medal, ridiculous speed that seldom stops moving in the chaotic brew of prehistoric beats.-You'll have little time to reset before the next incident occurs and for those seeking mindless thrills, this movie's pace does extraordinarily well with that.-And it really adds to the chaos if I'm being honest.The Visuals To A Point:
-The movie is using its budget well to bring these ancient beasts to life and the definition for the most part is great.-Animation is the solid point, fluid, anatomical, and feeling a bit more in tune with natural movements compared to the lower budget
-And the environments they generate are fantastic in regards to where we play, especially in the titular trench when we are down there.-To say they truly added the Hollywood spectacle of action meets monster is an understatement and this movie almost gloats for how much they did to make this film emerge from the depths.The Acting:
-It's no Oscar performance, but the team delivers a high caliber Sci-Fi movie performance compared to a lot of the media.-Curtis reprises his usual role. He's snippy, serious, a figure head that knows how to roll with these productions and fit well. A great ballast point that works with his crew.-Wu is a nice addition to the film. A tad complex at the beginning, but then turns his action and comedy roots for the second part of the film that somehow really works in the cheesy fun angle.-And Statham is Statham. You don't get much variety, but what you get is consistency and that perfect cheese factor. Dry, blunt, action oriented, with enough vulnerability to give his character more.It's really a perfect center for all the crew put together, with a chemistry that feels very much like this genre expects to be delivered: fun, loyal, and quite competent.The First Part:
-It might be a bit jumbled at the start, but the first act of the film held some potential for a new direction of the movie.-Jonas and his crew are once more in a world that they don't want to be in, and what they discover and explore in the trench accomplishes something the first one didn't.-The movie has elements of horror with its campiness, crafting a nightmarish world that like 2020's Underwater, works to convey the pressures of the deep.-Add some elements of Deep Impact, the Abyss, and Deep Blue Sea and you have this combination that works to be discomforting, but fun as the first leg of the story opens up.-It's probably the component that is the best balanced for me in terms of quality and 'quality' alongside visuals for 3-D to make good with.The Sound:
-I know most don't care about this, but the sound may be about a third of the reason this movie has the "bite" it does.-Science fiction films require some techniques to make the world even more immersive and Meg 2 does not shy away from giving your ears as much of an experience as your eyes.-Immense roars of the denizens of the deep are the start, alongside the breaths, screams, and cries of the humans that engage with them.-While the second part of the film is all about chaotic crunching, crashing, and all other sounds you associate when it comes to a movie like say, Godzilla.-It's loud and obnoxious, but in a film like this, almost a staple when it comes to the carnage at hand with these beasts.The Comedy:
-The movie's highest point for me is the comedy and how they balance it.-Meg 2 is just going to be a hilarious movie at how ridiculous the concept is and how loose they play with the physics. There are actually jokes bashing itself for just how crazy the theories are.-And when you throw in the "extra acting" factor, the movie is again that stupidity and ignorance that fans of the genre love when it comes to these over the top films.-The real brilliance though comes in two or three factors for me and more so how though ever present, is not as obnoxious as other movies tend to do.-One: Nostalgia and references of the past being used to joke about how absurd the film is now and how idiotic they were.-Two: The banter and sarcasm are well balanced and fun. Stupid? Absolutely. But the acting and the expectations of the genre welcome it and I laughed at the dialogue a lot ,probably more than I should have.-Three: The Character DJ, Page Kennedy, was my favorite character. He was competent, he evolved, he was stupid, but he was fun. Kennedy took great lines and made it his own, that though a bit in your face, were timed, balanced, and held a point.-This may be the biggest fun and quality of life in the movie and probably the reason I had as much fun as I did.DISLIKES:
Predictable:
-No surprise, these movies have been done to death and don't hold much surprises for people like me.-The movie lays out what it's going to do, pretty much sets up who won't make it, and how they are going to. So to lack surprise is a dig for me and something this movie could have done better with.The Opening Scene/Scenes:
-Meg 2's trailer is pretty much almost the entire opening sequence, at least the TV spot.-However, outside of technology show off, it's purpose is pretty much flat, pointless, and dare I say a waste of time to the story or even the relevance.-Even the next scene holds very little outside of a Statham stunt show, which comes later and more relevant, but tries to hastily set up what's been going on the past six years since the last film.-I think there were better ways to do this with more relevance, but... it's short lived and lost to the rest of the film that most aren't going to care.The Pace In Terms of Suspense:
-That first part of the movie I told you about held so much promise for a return to the more serious Science Fiction films.-It set that out well, until nearing the end of it, where the pace sort of amped up how many people go out in this film.-Movies like Underwater and Deep Blue Sea, with similar tones, played around with survival a bit more, and I had hoped for something similar given how this film started.-Once this point happens, the pace and handling of characters is kind of loose and loses this element, something I wish had been held on more to add that little engagement factor I like.The Absurdity Gets A Little Out Of Hand:
-The critics calling the whole thing a bloated mess are correct to a point, but that's what I expected going into this film.-However, the movie does sometimes take it a tad too far that does dip the quality of the film, though escapists and super fans do appreciate it.-No spoilers, but at time the carnage gets a little much, and seeing angles of people getting swallowed whole gets a tad boring, flat, and silly.-Other times, how idiotic many of the people are is a bit much, really only acting as more encouragement for mindless chaos and comedy that works with the cheesy humor, but again goes a tad too much.-And then to sort of change up the consistency and competency of the beasts, well the pace got a bit ahead of itself to wrap up in two hours.The CGI effects:
-The movie has improved on some levels, but I can't say it's the most realistic thing I've seen.-For one thing, I know they could do it, as we've seen the impossible brought to life with the technology of the modern era. And while I didn't need everything to look like what they did with LOTR, original Jurassic Park, etc.... a little more work could have helped.-I know, that's part of the genre, we've seen this so many times. But given the budget and advancements since then, I guess I would have pushed for a little more to just sort of stand out other than an impressive submerged world.THE VERDICT:
Meg 2: The Trench is a film that many are calling right, just a big, loud, messy film that is so off the wall cheesy and silly that you wonder how it exists. But.... The movie is fun and a big bout of escaping the real world for just that mindless fun that original Sci-Fi channel did so well in the 90s and 2000s. It uses the theater well, alongside the 3-D visuals, making it a theater worthy film for guys like me just in how everything comes together for the experience. While the acting is not Barbie and Oppenheimer level, it's fun and quality for this movie that met expectations and made it fun to go on the ride. And given the pace of the film, that fun is magnified in order to take the comedy written into the film, to massive proportions that I think is the best part of this film. It has fun with itself, gives you this cornball adventure with survival, and makes it a point they recognize how stupid it all sounds. Of course it does have problems in terms of an overall movie rating that some might not like. There are pointless scenes that showboat the computer effects, it gets out of hand like most films and runs too far with the absurdity, and the pace ends up tearing up some of the building moments to meet the time limits. The transition from the tense first part to the over the top second part can also be a bit of a jump, but if you can deflect that and know it was going this direction, you'll be fine. Attempting to factor all of this in, I give the movie the following scores:Action/Adventure/Horror: 7.5
Movie Overall: 6.0.

title: One time watchable
text: In 'The Meg 2: The Trench,' the film goes full-throttle right from the get-go, and while some might find this approach a tad disappointing, the sequel wears its intentions proudly on its sleeve, making it effortless to hop aboard this whimsical rollercoaster. The movie boldly asks us to suspend disbelief as it presents Jonas, our intrepid hero, with a seemingly improbable feat: surviving 500 atmospheres of crushing deep-sea pressure. However, it's not just because he's portrayed by Jason Statham; the film's logic hinges on a clever twist. In this aquatic world, unlike in the airy realm above, water doesn't yield to pressure; hence, all Jonas needs to do is replace the air in his lungs with water - a seemingly simple solution that adds an extra layer of zany charm to the narrative.This level of absurdity would spell disaster for a more earnest cinematic endeavor, but 'The Meg 2: The Trench' embraces it with gusto, proudly wearing its ludicrousness as a badge of honor. Remarkably, the audience not only accepts this audacious approach but wholeheartedly embraces it, fully aware that they've invested their hard-earned money for a spectacle of CGI shark mayhem, and boy, do they get it in spades.In this sequel, the stakes are even higher with the introduction of not one, not two, but three Megs, and as a special treat, a Kraken is thrown into the mix as a bonus monster. But hold on, there's more! Deep within the titular trench, a place where creatures have evolved in isolation for countless millennia with no contact with the terrestrial world, we're introduced to four-legged amphibians that can casually amble about on land and breathe as though it's a walk in the park. Because, well, why not? What truly matters is that there's a relentless onslaught of sea monsters attacking from every conceivable direction, whether it's on land or beneath the waves.For those curious about the storyline, Jonas naturally makes his return, but the love interest from the first installment has met a tragic fate, leaving him in the role of a surrogate father to her daughter, Meiying, played by the spirited Shuya Sophia Cai. It's a move straight out of the contemporary filmmaking playbook - the 'family' card, an easy ploy employed by many modern movies to connect with audiences. Meiying, as expected, embodies the archetype of the precocious movie kid who defies Jonas's guidance at every turn, often placing herself in perilous situations. Yet, in the spirit of delivering a thrilling and enjoyable cinematic experience, this film ensures that the adorable youngster always manages to come through unscathed. With only a few exceptions, the victims here are typically unsavory characters whose unfortunate fate as shark bait doesn't exactly leave us shedding tears.Introducing a fresh face to the mix, we meet Meiying's uncle, Jiuming Zhang, portrayed by Jing Wu. He presides over a remarkable underwater facility and has a peculiar companion in the form of a Megalodon named Haiqi. Zhang's nurturing approach involves clicker-training this colossal sea creature, akin to taming a puppy-a narrative element reminiscent of Chekov's Gun, a detail that the film momentarily appears to misplace but later reclaims with a surprising twist near the climax. This unexpected turn almost serves as a dramatic payoff, adding an intriguing layer to the story.Regarding the marauding sea creatures, the CGI work may appear somewhat rough around the edges, with that characteristic glossy, almost surreal appearance. However, given that the entire film essentially embraces a live-action cartoon aesthetic, these visual quirks are hardly a deal-breaker. One commendable aspect is the distinct look of the massive Alpha Meg, whose weathered hide bears a tapestry of scars reminiscent of Moby Dick. It's as if the scars narrate a history of battles, a testament to age, resilience, and power. Although it doesn't exactly imbue the Meg with a personality, it does render him iconic, and one can't help but wish for a more personalized showdown between him and Jonas-the two resilient alpha males hurtling toward a confrontation where only one will emerge victorious.Perhaps such depth was too much to expect, but at least Haiqi, the pet Meg, assumes a pivotal albeit enigmatic role in the climax. Is she merely following her predatory instincts, or has she forged a connection with Zhang? The script's Chekov's Gun moment leaves us genuinely uncertain about the outcome. However, rest assured, the narrative ties up as neatly as sashimi in a fish market ravaged by a hurricane, which is about as tidy as one can hope for in a film with such a staggering, uncountable body count.The lingering question on our minds is whether 'Meg 3' will take the concept of clicker-training to new extremes, potentially crafting a scenario reminiscent of 'Jurassic World,' wherein a disciplined pack of Megalodons could serve as a team of aquatic attack dogs. It might sound utterly absurd, but let's not forget that embracing the ridiculousness is precisely what made 'The Meg 2' such a delightful surprise.

title: Not quite as Mega as the first, but still a fun monster movie!
text: When it comes to giant monster movies, Meg 2: The Trench ticks most of the boxes you'd want to be ticked. While not quite as strong as the first film (which I personally loved) it's still a mostly solid sequel.The opening and set-up work nicely, followed by some creepy trench exploration that's possibly the most horror-esque sequence throughout both of the Meg films. The movie slows down a little during its second act, however, and the monster action takes a backseat for a fairly uninteresting action/eco-terrorist plot... but Meg 2 is mostly saved by going full throttle once again in the finale, with plenty of sharky, tentacly, lizardy, Jason Stathamy goodness to go around.All in all, Meg 2 is probably a fairly strong 7/10, if you enjoy these kinds of popcorn movies. I hope they keep making these, or at least round things off with a third instalment. We've gotta have Jason Statham riding a megalodon into battle, after all!

title: Heavy of the Fiction, light on the Science.
text: A Middle School Play about sharks My twelve year old could write a better sequel. I usually allow for a bit of movie logic, but this isn't charming enough. At the bottom of the trench, there is about 8 tons of pressure. Things like walking from another station in a suit would take hours (longer than any air supply) and rising to the surface quickly would be fatal. Most actors don't realize how bad a movie is going to be during the process of filming. Jason Statham's acting is a bright spot in a dull movie. Most of the action is preposterous. The dialogue is horrible. Despite this, the last 10 minutes are somewhat entertaining.

title: Popcorn movie ahoy!
text: Really not sure about those low ratings here?! What did you expect? Citizen Kane?!Watch this movie on the big screen is my recommendation and leave your brain in standby mode, this is pure dumb action/excitement!It picks up from not too long after the first movie with most of the same likeable characters.All the boxes are ticked including the standard double crossing, guessing who's going to die, dumb bad guys, dumb good guys...sorry Jason...and of course a cheesy ending!I went with my 2 older daughters and all of us enjoyed it, my youngest laughing her head; which ain't a bad thing!Great fun.

title: I knew it would be like this but I still watched it...
text: No one can be accused of thinking a sequel to 2018's 'The Meg' would be a high-quality piece of cinema. In 'Meg 2: The Trench,' we get taken on another ridiculous ride in the South China Sea with perennial badass Jason Statham as the oceanic explorer Jonas Taylor and his motley crew.This has everything you don't need in a movie - fake-looking CGI sharks, hundreds of near-misses/buzzer beaters, poorly-timed jokes, plot holes, bad acting and more. Granted, 'Meg 2' was never going to be a good film, but it's surprising how it feels like two completely different movies in one. The first half, while far from great, is at least interesting given the emphasis is not solely on the film's namesake (and feels like a slightly better version of that Kristen Stewart movie from a few years ago). But once things hit the halfway point, everything quite literally jumps the shark.Unfortunately for all of us, 'Meg 2' did alright at the box office, which means we'll probably be seeing a continuation of this saga at sea. And while we absolutely do not need to watch it, we probably still will.

title: It's a movie worth seeing
text: The two main characters in this film are working very hard. There are rich visual effects scenes, rich Marine wonders, a variety of Marine animals dazzled, indeed give the audience a certain surprise, Wu Jing's addition is the movie action more wonderful, the whole movie does have laughter and tears, worth seeingIn addition, the double protagonist setting of this film also makes the whole film process have a different feeling, as a deep-sea shark commercial film, the overall movie feeling is smooth and complete, looking forward to the thirdOverall, this is a movie worth watching, full of unexpected surprises and action-packed scenes.

title: We Love Pippin!
text: I read in the box office reports, about this film, before I saw it, that the writers and producers wanted to go heavier, with the comedy angle for Meg 2: The Trench (2023), compared to the amount seen in the first film. This worried me a little, because what I liked the most about the Meg (2018), was its goal to stay out of Sharknado territory (a made-for-TV film from 2013, about tornados, containing sharks) and try to teeter closer to Jaws (1975), type-of-quality territory, instead. The first film managed to do that, but landed slightly between Jaws 2 (1978) and Jaws 3-D (1983). Anyway, I liked the Meg (2018). The plot in Meg 2: The Trench (2023), establishes, that the film takes place in current day, 2023. In this 2023, our team of divers, with their very futuristic-looking equipment, head to the bottom of the sea, this time, to 25,000 feet, to test out the equipment. They also, after just five years, have a pet megalodon. More on that later.Completely opposite to the first film, this time, Jason Statham's seasoned diver, Jonas Taylor, jumps right into action, rather enthusiastically, for this test run. He wasn't that excited, nor enthusiastic, to get into things in the first film. In the Meg 2: The Trench (2023), Taylor and the gang, have to deal, with multiple megs, a giant octopus, lizard-like Snappers (which are pulled, right out of science-fiction) and a group of bad-guys, who hijack the diver's home base and strand Taylor and crew, on the bottom of the ocean. When I saw the Meg (2018), I was bad, with preparing for the movie, didn't do my homework and found out, before seeing this movie, that the Meg movies, are based off of a group of novels, by a guy named, Steve Alten. I guess, he is the modern-day version of Clive Cussler, with the added touch of dinosaurs. So, knowing that, helps set the narrative more for these films and explains a lot.In Meg 2: The Trench (2023), I wasn't expecting a classically-designed bad-guy (Sergio Peris-Mencheta as Montes), with aspirations of nefarious goals, leading a group of mercenaries and not worried about wrecking the world. I just thought Meg 2: The Trench (2023), would just contain more sea monsters and dangers of the deep. This was a problem though, because I felt Montes, was one of the clumsiest, laziest, idiot-like, bad-guys, I've seen in a while. In this film, if you look closely, he doesn't accomplish anything. Taylor has no problem, tossing this guy around. It was kind of laughable to watch the Montes character in this film. I mean, really, the closest thing to a human bad-guy in the last film, was Rainn Wilson's, greedy, billionaire businessman, Jack Morris. But, he actually is the best character in that film and one you love to hate. His presence is missed in this film. He also was responsible for some of the best lines and comedy-relief moments from the last film. In this film, the comedy one-liners were dispersed throughout, with the rest of the cast. Rainn Wilson was missed. I know, it's impossible. How about a twin brother? Just kidding.Along with Statham, other returning champs come back for the second film, such as, Page Kennedy as DJ and Cliff Curtis as Mac. They get to try the jokes out and even though, they couldn't match Rainn Wilson level, they still were good enough. Both guys, especially Curtis, are pretty good actors. One of the problems with Meg 2: The Trench (2023), was the pet megalodon sub-plot. So, I am being a little facetious here, when I say, "pet megalodon". It's actually their captive, baby megalodon, who can be, slightly controlled by audio clicks, produced by scientist-diver, Jiuming Zhang (Wu Jing). This "relationship", which wasn't silly at all, just ended up being a useless part of the story. I kept forgetting about the "good" megalodon. I did like Wu Jing's character though. A nice touch to this film, was the return of Pippin, the dog, which is a great homage to Jaws (1975). Pippin had a hilarious moment in Meg (2018). My fear about Meg 2: The Trench (2023), didn't happen, too much. The comedy usage was about the same, with, maybe, a little more comedy in this one, but that helped dampen the slow start-up, in the beginning of the film. The first film, just flowed, a little bit better. No pun intended.6.1 (D+ MyGrade) = 6 IMDB.

title: An Expensive Sharknado
text: Now, the first Meg was no oscar winner, but it was a fun action movie. Statham always delivers. But even he couldnt save this ridiculousness.Plot...well, it kind of had to do with giant prehistoric sharks, but not really. It was more like Jurassic Park under water...until oh wait, it turned into regular Jurassic Park. Huh?And I understand one must suspend disbelief for this type of movie, dinosaurs and all, but the fantasy technology (underwater suits, computers, radar, comms, weapons) were also just too over the top.Overall a mish mash of bad acting, weak and cheesey characters, and cartoon-like stunts. It reminded me at times of those bad SyFy channel movies...this is just a really expensive version of Sharknado. Just another bad idea. Lazy film making.

title: As written by a 5th grade boy
text: Insipid, stupid, and just plain wrong. Everything about this film feels like it was written and directed by a 5th grade boy. No basis in reality. No rhyme or reason. And the dialogue (if you want to call it that) is ridiculous.Now, if Jason would have taken off his shirt or at least appeared half interested in the film, it might have been ok. But he is clearly phoning it in scene after scene.After awhile, you start rooting for the animals. And what exactly is this movie about? Saving the environment? Mining for treasures? Showing what sharks sort of but not really look like??Do yourself and your brain a HUGE favor and avoid this like the plague.

title: This movie has an identity crisis..
text:
The first part of the movie , well more like 2/3's was trying to be a suspense/ action movie w a bit of sci-fi, and drama...then it turned into a comedy/horror failed attempt at camp flick. Essentially this film is a "what not to do when making a film in any genre 101" . I gave it a 2 or 3 stars because I actually don't even think there's anything the actors could do to save the script so the acting isn't even the worse part.What I expected and what it was...
I didn't expect this to be scary but at least have some jump scares and a bit of excitement and some cohesive story however I found myself fast forwarding through most of the first half's dialogue because it was that boring. The action scenes are pretty bad with overdone Cgi making it hard to even follow what is happening in the scene. I actually kept forgetting some scenes were supposed to be under water as it didn't resemble water at all, it looked more like bad space scenes.Another issue was the way the actors were so unaffected by things, like when their friends and family are possibly dead the rest of the crew acts so matter of fact that it leaves the viewer not caring either.It's a good movie to keep on while doing house work since there's only a couple ok scenes and the storyline is pretty dumb.

title: Storyline was just so so
text: I guess Chinese production was involved with this film because two of the main casts are Chinese (not well known) and also quite a lot of Chinese dialog in this movie. The storyline was not super thrilling, however, it did keep me focus most of the film. The scenes weren't too violent.I guess Chinese production was involved with this film because two of the main casts and background actors are Chinese (not well known) and also quite a lot of Chinese dialog in this movie. The storyline was not super thrilling, however, it did keep me focus most of the film. The fighting and attacking scenes weren't too violent.

title: No Good without the Bingbing...
text: Everything, and I do mean EVERYTHING, that made the first movie the biggest shock and surprise since Jaws...everything is GONE. Aside from a strong neo-Jurassic flashback at the opening, this movie spends the first hour wasting everybody's time with a bunch of noise and a big mess of chaos that meant absolutely nothing...But after about an hour (it took them long enough), they finally make it to a bikini beach. Not sure exactly what they were there for, but the Meg was somewhere off shore, and between the bikinis and the giant shark this movie, briefly, hit a stride similar to the first one. They managed to correct the BIG mistake they made, when they chose to film this sequel without the Bingbing herself. The movie barely avoids becoming a big, unwatchable mess.Even so, not using Li Bingbing was inexplicably DUMB. There was a motherlode of a story around her, her daughter and the male lead that would have made this movie seriously worth watching. As it stands, this thing barely made it.

title: More like Not Enough Meg 2: The Average.
text: Meg 2: The Trench continues with the adventures of Jonas Taylor(Jason Statham), after the events of The Meg(2018). Jonas & his research team come across multiple deadly creatures, while exploring the extreme depths of the ocean, while also dealing with a sinister mining operation.Meg 2: The Trench is just about passable. Director Ben Wheatley has unsuccessfully taken over the reins from The Meg(2018) director, Jon Turtelaub. This film is not even half as entertaining as its predecessor. The first half of the movie is a proper snooze fest. There's barely any action set pieces or the titular prehistoric shark, with an unnecessary environmental conservation subplot thrown in. The second half of the film makes up for it though. It's supremely fun with mind-blowing action set pieces & lots of guffaw-inducing moments. The 3D is worth it finally, after that tedious first half. Jason Statham is spectacular as Jonas Taylor. Jing Wu is superb as Jiuming Zhang. Shuya Sophia Kai is fantastic as Meiying. Cliff Curtis is awesome as Mac. Page Kennedy is hysterical as DJ. Sergio Peris-Mencheta is good as Montes. Skyler Samuels is perfect as Jess. Melissanthi Mahut is awesome as Rigas. Sienna Guillory is amazing as Driscoll. The supporting cast is memorable. Meg 2: The Trench is not a must watch in theatres or at home, because of its subpar story. Just watch it, if you have some time to kill.

title: Some sequels should never be made
text: The original Meg was fun and exciting. Meg 2, the sequel... Not so much... Horrible acting and it was excruciatingly painful to watch not so fun to watch. Predictable. Boring. I definitely would not recommend this to anyone. Personally, I think the actors should give the money they 'earned' for this back as should the writer. Poorly written storyline. Too many massive holes in the plot. Never kill off a favorite actress before she even gets into the second movie. The only reason I watched it was for the chemistry between the two main characters from the first movie. I am really really glad I did not waste money to see this in the theater.

title: Overall Enjoyable
text: If you can let yourself have fun during a movie, you'll enjoy it. Not nearly as bad a movie as some are saying. (Although definitely not as good as the first.) I think the writers (1) focused too much on writing a story where other people were the villains, as opposed to making it a straight shark movie, and (2) got a little overly ambitious with the multiple megs, giant squid, and weird lizard things. Some things I think also defied the laws of physics, but again, sometimes we just need to suspend our disbelief during movies. I still liked it. Was happy to see Pippin the dog reprise his role!

title: Silly Shark Story
text: It's back! And not bigger and better than ever. Several megalodons threaten a Chinese billionaire, Jason Statham and his crew from the last movie but unfortunately poor CGI makes the action sequences with sea creature seem cartoonish and not at all threatening. The story is functional based on the deep sea novel, The Trench, but the narrative set ups are basically there to create shark encounters where you wonder who's going to live or die. There is an even a nod (a rip-off?) of Jurassic Park with stubby land dinosaurs too. Either way the creatures look like CGI creatures and don't really move like animals do in real life.Statham is decent as always in these flicks and the supporting cast is likeable enough including Jing Wu as the billionaire and Shuya Sophia Cai as his niece. But a likeable cast isn't enough to carry this film when the ridiculous action sequences strain credibility, especially Statham flexing superhero strength in the final climatic moment. My favorite part of the film was the end credit song because 1) I enjoyed listening to it 2) it meant the movie was over.

title: Not great
text:
It was decent but way too many jaws references. Seems no one has an original thought or plot for movies anymore! Everyone just makes remakes or copies parts of other movies. That had it moments tho. For the times you would think they could make Jason riding a jet ski look more realistic. Instead it just looks like bad green screen work. The animal look more real than the action shots do. Glad I didn't pay money to watch this in the theaters.The villains are more a filler than much else. They
Really didn't need to be in the film to make it work much differently. Just made Jason's job of trying to rid the world of the megs a bit tougher.

title: Everything Wrong with Film Today
text: The Meg 2 is the worst movie to come out since The Meg. When I watch movies like it (why do I torture myself?), I often feel like I'm watching something made by an alien species. The scripts and acting performances are so inhuman that they're unsettling, and even though this is a dumb monster movie, the special effects look like they were done with 30-year-old technology. When you combine it all - awful writing, awful acting, awful direction, awful editing, awful effects, awful EVERYTHING - you get this a movie like this, one that makes you question why the universe gave you a consciousness in the first place if you're just wasting it on stuff like this. Let that sink in: this movie was so bad it made me question humanity's purpose in the universe. I hope all these corporate shills enjoyed the slim paycheck they got from creating this trash.

title: A Fun Dumb Shark Movie that is Nothing like the Book
text: Yeah so lets get this out of the way, this movie is really dumb. It's not a good movie. And the only things it has in common with the book is the title and the Megaladon.That being said it was a lot of fun. My biggest issue with the first film (aside from accuracy to the book) was the fact that it felt like the film was trying to be like "Jaws" and "Deep Blue Sea" at the same time with the issue being those are two completely different shark movies. One is grounded in reality, the other is essentially science fiction. "Meg 2" however felt like it was just trying to be "Deep Blue Sea". Throw reality out the window and have some fun.If you are looking for the version of The Meg that is reminiscent of "Jaws" then my advice would be to read the books, they are awesome. If you just want to fun yet dumb shark movie then "Meg 2: The Trench" is perfect.

title: Time I cannot get back!
text: The first Meg was outrageous, campy, but still a lot of fun. The Meg 2: The Trench (Such a horrible title) takes itself to seriously and forgets that this film is supposed to be campy/outrageous. Instead we get a film that shows less Megs and more action between humans. If I wanted to see that I would have popped in another Jason Statham film. Honestly though this movie had a very weak story/plot and was very boring at times. Also the CGI seemed to be a lot worse then the first film which is hard to believe because I do think this one had the bigger budget. Everyone that starred in this film probably did it to just collect a paycheck. Trust me when I say this "Save your time!" Go watch another movie because this movie is a complete insult to audiences. The Meg 2: The Trench should have stayed buried deep down below in a trench. This film gets a very weak 3 stars out of 10 for me.

title: Not as good as the part one
text: The problem is you can expect everything what's gonna happen next adding a octopus in climax wasn't that intresting either.And why the hell did you kill Bing Bing Lee man she was good in the part and my first reason to watch film was because of her.It felt like there was lack maturity in many scenes it really felt so childish. Even Jason Statham couldn't do much his funny reactions and trying to do comedy didn't work at all could have been made much better because from the beginning to end there only one thing Megalodon the movie name is meg doesn't mean meg should be eating all the screen time.

title: Everything was predictable
text:
The Meg One
Director Jon Turteltaub
Writers Dean Georgaris, Jon Hoeber, Erich Hoeber
screenplay by Dean Georgaris, Jon Hoeber, and Erich Hoeber
Produced by Lorenzo di Bonaventura, Belle Avery, Colin WilsonThe Meg Two: the trench
Director Ben Wheatley
Writers Jon Hoeber, Erich Hoeber, Dean Georgaris, Steve Alten.Story by Dean Georgaris, Jon Hoeber, Erich Hoeber.Produced by Lorenzo di Bonaventura, Belle Avery.So, they dropped the director and a producer from Meg 1 and added a new director and writer to Meg 2. Somewhere in the shuffle, althought this had the makings of a great movie, it totally lost it. Everything was predictable, and not believable.If you enjoyed Meg 1, then I recommend you avoid Meg 2, unless you like Jason Statham so much you can't pass it by.

title: Such a stupid movie
text: This is a total time waster. These kind of movies can be a bit dramatic, but this is beyond the boundaries.1. Jason Statham is more stronger than a meg according to the movie.2. CGI sucks.3. Making a teenager a hero - Seriously we are fedup of this now. Movies like Godzilla, Black-Adam, Meg, Pacific-Rim-2 and so many other movies, they try to make teens heroes. They might think that will attract people but that actually destroys the thrill. All these movies are failures and directors never learn.4. Very weak script. No character building and there were some twists but it doesn't feel like give us any thrills.

title: Annoying
text: Having a Chinese lead that doesn't speak English is extremely annoying. It's obvious he dubbed his own lines, so it loses all expression. It sounds like a theater play. Take a hint from Jackie Chan or even Arnold Schwarzenegger. Half the time they have no idea what they're saying, but at least it conveys the emotion.Otherwise decent actors, stupid plot, your typical B movie. Statham does his usual shtick, it's ok I guess.The cinematography is not really up to scratch. Especially the underwater action scenes in the first half of the movie are only tolerable. The second half is slightly better, but still not up to what you'd expect these days.

title: MEGA-DULL
text: This feels more like a rejected TV pilot than a movie. The dialogue, acting, pacing and general story are all a generic bore. The title creature is barely in the film at all!
