The last 5 or 10 minutes are really the only portion worth watching, and even then, it's hardly worth the wait, (though if the rest of the film was better, it would add to its impact or entertainment value).Jason Statham simply has no juicy writing to chew on, so apart from some over the top action sequences, he's pretty much wasted.Billed as a comedy, there's no real trace of any humour, apart from the occasional groanworthy remark.The villains are strictly cardboard too.

title: Utter Magnificent Madness
text: Utter magnificence madness, pure fun from beginning to end. Those familiar with Ben Wheatley's signature flair from films like "Kill List" and "In the Earth" might be taken aback by the sheer audacity and thrill he brings to "Meg 2: The Trench." Unlike his previous venture, "Rebecca," Wheatley dives deep, and not just into the ocean's abyss.Jason Statham, reprising his role as Jonas, the deep-sea diver from the Zhang Institute, brings an energy that's hard to miss. While the first film introduced us to the prehistoric terror, the Megalodon, this sequel takes a twist. Jiuming, played by the ever-versatile Wu Jing, believes he can tame the beast. But as fate would have it, chaos ensues, and not just from the giant shark.Rather than a mere chase, Wheatley takes us on a journey to the megalodon's home, the trench. But the real surprise? An unexpected human adversary lurking in the shadows, exploiting the ocean's treasures. The sequences, especially one involving a treacherous walk on the ocean floor, are executed with a finesse that only Wheatley can deliver.Amidst the chaos, the bond between Jonas and Meiying (Sophia Cai) stands out, offering a touch of humanity in a world of monsters. And just when you think the film might be losing its bite, Wheatley throws in a twist, bringing the action right to a tourist hotspot. The climax is a spectacle, a testament to Wheatley's ability to blend horror, action, and dark humor seamlessly.However, what truly stands out is Wheatley's refusal to conform. While the narrative might seem familiar, his execution is anything but. It's not just about the shark or the hero saving the day; it's about the journey, the thrill, and the unexpected turns.In a world where imagination sets the limit, "Meg 2: The Trench" proves that there's no boundary to cinematic brilliance. Dive in, the waters are just right.Enjo the film for what it is.

title: Stupid shark movie that isn't a shark movie
text: This flick is about the Megalodon, a giant prehistoric shark that lives in the deepest parts of the ocean. If you expect something like Jaws you will be very disappointed. In this film, the sharks play almost a marginal role. It seems like the director thought that Megalodon sharks aren't scary enough so let's throw in some dinosaurs, a giant octopus and terrorists on top of that. That will make the movie sufficiently exhilarating, or not. It's like they decided to mix Jaws with Jurassic Park and Mission Impossible. The result is an action movie where a lot of things happen simultaneously, but where there is lack of story and character development. What basically drives the plot are the special effects. But there is nothing new in that department. We have already seen computer animated sharks and monsters in various film before (for the last 20 years or so). The characters are stereotypes to say the least. Like in any action movie there are good guys and bad guys fighting each other and once in a while a Megalodon shark pops up on the screen. For me this was an unrealistic and boring film that deserves the lowest possible rating.

title: Barely passable as a movie
text: Meg 2 is a prime example of a movie that could've been way better of it were rated R. The script is not good, but many movies don't have to have a good script in order to be a fun movie. These movies have other things that hold your attention and provide a cheer factor to round out your enjoyment.The plot is over-complicated. It's been a few weeks since I've seen it, but I forgot about the plot while I was actively watching it. There's too many characters, and not enough good lines to make any of them stand out other than Jason Stratham who brings charisma that he doesn't need to try at. The main draw is the sharks. For the first half of the movie you wade patiently you wait for them to show up and have to sit through some okay plotting and ridiculous scenes, the most "fun" being Stratham surviving bare-skinned at 25,000 feet. It's at this point that only some incredible shark action can save the movie, but what we get is very boring action that seems only a third finished. The other two-thirds, gore and interesting action set pieces, were left on the production's PG-13 budget floor.Meg 2 is not devoid of certain fun. It's watchable, but I would never recommend it to be watched. There's plenty of other movies that are the same as this one, but do everything better. If it were bloody and slipped in R rated material throughout, then you could at least have fun with it, but the direction it chose to go ultimately made it a forgettable movie that no one could be proud of.

title: Mega Action
text: As a stand alone shark movie this was very good and had no shortage of action. As expected from a sequel the effects were bigger and the creatures more frightening. The number of close calls was magnified almost as much as the number of teeth in this one.However, as a sequel, it mostly missed the mark as most of the character relations and chemistry from the first one was almost completely missing. The My Two Dads story line just doesn't invest viewers with the characters.As a book adaptation, this left me wondering, even more than the first one, just when will Steve Alten's excellent story be told on the big Screen.

title: Where were the Megs!?
text: Our favourite eco warrior and occasional shark hunter Jonas Taylor (played by Jason Statham) is back for another encounter with the Megalodon. Jonas is asked to board the Mana One's new high tech underwater research facility, but this time, he is surprised to see that the scientists are doing research directly on a female Meg named Haiqi who freely swims around its waters. Also on board are some familiar faces: Mac (Cliff Curtis), DJ (Page Kennedy) and the now teenage Meiying (Shuya Sophia Cai) who have all been assisting Meiying's uncle Jiuming (Jing Wu) train Haiqi. Notable additions to the cast are analyst Jess (Skyler Samuels), and wealthy financier Hillary Driscoll (Sienna Guilroy).Jonas and his colleagues obviously haven't learnt their lesson about going down to the Mariana Trench and through the thermocline, as they decide to explore it yet again, this time in submersibles that are eerily similar to the ill-fated OceanGate one that imploded in June 2023. Whilst down there, they encounter 2 Megs, an enormous male alpha and a slightly smaller (but still quite large) male. Little do they know; it is mating season and their friendly pet Haiqi has escaped captivity so she can have some fun with the boys (wink wink). Tragedy occurs on the sea floor, leaving Jonas' group no choice but to abandon their vehicles in search of safety. Luckily there is an illegal mining operation in a station not far that the group can aim to seek shelter in. The group's efforts are foiled by bad guy Montes (Sergio Peris-Mencheta) and his team of mercenaries who plan to kill Jonas and his remaining crew in order to keep their mining plans a secret. When the groups are finally able to reach the surface and find a heavily populated island, the Megs follow them (along with some other deep-sea hitchhikers), resulting in chaos.This film is silly, and it really leans into that. Comparisons could be made between it and terrible sci fi channel shark films like the Sharknado franchise and the more recent and similar The Black Demon (2023), but thankfully, what sets this apart is its amazing graphics and CGI. Instead of using awful stock footage and replaying video of sharks swimming from multiple angles, this film's big budget is put to good use. The water effects are extremely realistic, and the texture and overall look of its prehistoric creatures was akin to those of Jurassic Park. The giant octopus' CGI was less successful though, but I understand that it would have been a challenge to animate it with what it did.I loved that Jason Statham was able to show off in this film, and the fact that he did all of his own stunts was impressive, but not surprising given that he's a previous Olympic diver! There were some fun Easter eggs too, like the little dog Pippin and its owner from the first film having a cameo, but it was a bit strange that it wasn't pointed out at all (I mean, what are the chances of a woman and her dog encountering Megalodons twice in the span of 5 years? Talk about a coincidence!)There was a lot about this film that frustrated me, and although it was a fantasy film, the level of realism was almost laughable. Some examples of this were how characters were able to be over 20,000 meters underwater and not feel the effects of its temperature or pressure, and there are even scenes where no diving gear was used. Now I'm no diving expert but even I know that's impossible. I also hated how there were several 'at the last second' moments throughout the film, from oxygen almost running out, to doors closing just in time and bombs going off just as every one of the main cast is safe. There were too many of these moments to count, but after two or three i started to roll my eyes.Sadly, almost everything was spoilt in the trailer for me, so there were no surprises. I felt like the eventual villain was obvious from the start, and I could have done without several unnecessary characters including Montes. Guilroy and Samuels' acting skills belonged in a sci fi channel low budget shark movie, and not in this multi-million dollar blockbuster. Neither of them was successful in their character, and although Statham played his character well, the script was weak with some atrocious dialogue. There was one scene where a character notes that something is worth a billion dollars, and Statham responds with "A billion with a B?" C'mon man...Ultimately, Meg 2: The Trench was more of an action spy thriller than a horror film like its predecessor, and it sidelined the Megs to be secondary characters in order to focus on the action going on with the human characters. There was also a notable absence of blood and gore which felt like a missed opportunity to give the fans what they wanted, but I understand that it helped them achieve the MPAA rating that the film had by doing this. If there is a third film to come in the future, i say more blood, more gore and most importantly, more Megs!

title: How to ruin a franchise...
text: Meg 2 is to Meg 1 what Pacific Rim 2 was to Pacific Rin 1. Just in this case, they even had a good book series to work with which was not utilized. Instead, they ruined a good premise by going down the route of focusing more on people fighting (in the most nonsensical way) and having sea creatures as a side effect as opposed to building onto the first movie or the books to focus on a good Meg story. Bad CGI and the lack of attention to detail makes this a perfect way to end a franchise that could have become something great. I wish I had not gone to cinema for for this and had to apologize to my friends for dragging them into such a mess of a movie.

title: Exactly what you'd expect it to be.
text: The Meg was a fun B Movie with a budget. Great, self aware stuff. Could have been a bit crazier, gorier or more deliberate in humour or tone, but for what it was it was a good bit of schlocky fun. Meg 2: The Trench continues that trend about as well as it can, both in good and bad ways.The Trench promises plenty of Jason Statham, Shark, dinosaur and monster action. On this it absolutely delivers. The action here does feel trimmed down a little, like it was initially gorier but got edited for a fairer rating. Regardless, it's well done and thrilling and giddy stuff. Everyone in the movie seems to be completely on board with it too. They commit to the dialogue and treat it seriously, which helps the film feel more absurd and fun.The effects are fun, though not entirely convincing. The trench stuff looks great, but the scenes above or closer to the surface don't fare as well. But the style and energy of the film make up for that, and it never looks Sharknado or Scorpion King bad. It's pretty relentlessly paced too, so you're often caught up in the thrill before you see the strings.Where the film does suffer a bit is in the trench. At a certain point, while not boring, the film is absent of creature madness. And after a while you do miss them. Sure the opening and ending make up for it, it's just a bit unfortunate.In the end it certainly has the better moments, but The Meg is likely the better overall film. It's worth a watch for lovers of B Movie schlock and for those who only want what it sets out to deliver. It isn't great by any means, and certainly not for everyone. But it's very enjoyable nonetheless.

title: The movies is entertaining.
text: There are some movies where we can easily say the story to go and..... This movie falls in that category. I know many things don't make sense but there's a saying in India that 'If you are watching a movie, don't use much of your brain' and I think in some cases it is true. For its cinematography and CGI, I can excuse all the flaw it has and easily give it an A+ The underwater shots and many shots are there which we can make our wallpaper. I am not saying that the story's bad, story's simple and straightforward and that's not bad, it is good, I am just saying that they didn't do anything extraordinary. It is worth-watching. It's thrilling, exciting, fascinating, gory, decent, has a real good cast, the direction's good, they successfully showed the terror of a Megalodon, what happened or what they could do if they were alive, it is gory, it shows what happens when we try to play with the nature, there is a saying that 'If you play with nature, the nature will play with you and you are definitely not the winner'. The movie is entertaining enough to check it out more than one time for entertainment purpose.

title: Disaster of epic proportions
text: Usually I only review movies that I really like but after seeing the movie and seeing so many high marks here on IMDB I knew I had to write something.I watched the first movie and it was not good but the whole idea sounded really cool to me so I decided to give it a try with the sequel. I had low expectations but what I have seen is even worse than I could imagine.What did they try to do here???If they tried to make a comedy; the jokes were so bad that only a 5 year old could be amused.If they tried to make an action move; the action scenes were so lame, stupid and uninteresting you could die from boredom.If they tried to make a horror movie; I think viewers should at least be a little scared during the movie and that just doesn't exist.Maybe they were trying to make a musical but they forgot to put musical parts in the movie?The whole movie is just an insult to viewers intelligence so while watching you just keep asking yourself how much more stupid can it get.In the film there are so many stolen scenes from different movies (Jurassic park, Jaws, Deep blue sea ....) that I wonder how unoriginal they could be.The movie was a real waste of time and it will be forgotten in minutes after exiting theater.In the last part of the movie I was just waiting for everything to finally be finished that I can go home, sleep and forget about it.Try to avoid this movie if possible.I gave it 2 stars just because the preview looked nice.

title: Why.
text: This left me genuinely bored watching this movie.The characters kinda just show up without being established and so when a character dose anything die, cry, hug, talk, it feels extremely bland and unimportant they all feel like cannon fodder.Every time anything happens on screen you are left simply asking why. It might have worked for the movie if it was a comedic movie but the movie takes it self very very very seriously.The main characters do nothing whatsoever to stop the antagonist instead the villains slowly die off without the main characters even being there.Trust me the most interesting part of this movie is this review.

title: My expectations were low and I still was disappointed
text: Let me start by saying a sequel about a giant prehistoric killer shark is bound to fall short of a masterpiece in film. I really enjoyed the first Meg movie, even though it itself is not the greatest movie ever. The problem with this movie is it has too much going on. There are many prehistoric animals, underwater mining, a guy training a shark Jurassic World style, diving exosuits that can crush concrete blocks, mercenaries, a father and daughter finding common ground, at one point it's a buddy cop Die Hard esque movie, so much going on.The villains in this film are underwhelming. The CGI is one step above a Sharknado film. This just should have been so much better.

title: Jaws: Home Alone edition
text: The theme "Megaladon" should be interesting enough - but this movie is spoiling a great possibility to make a movie about the legend. It's slapstick-Jaws.Like so many movies before, this one also fall into the trap of going overboard - introducing other different species, more sharks and stereotype villains with extraordinary skills and survivalskills. Hope someday someone will make a "serious" movie about the Megaladon, as this almost became to stupid to even enjoy the faritale-side of it. Shallow characters, as like the rest of this story, which is into way to deep water for my taste. Sorry.

title: Formulaic, forgettable - but serves its purpose
text: I thought the original Meg movie was alright, so I decided to give Meg 2: The Trench (let's just call it The Trench from here on) a shot. In The Trench, Jonas Taylor (played by Jason Statham) returns to the ocean to confront a significant threat - a group of sea monsters that have been unleashed from the deep!The acting in The Trench is decent, although not particularly noteworthy. Jason Statham does his usual competent job as the main character but the supporting cast doesn't leave a lasting impression. The characters themselves lack development or complexity. The story follows the formulaic structure of most monster movies without much deviation from the norm. While survival is obviously the theme, it's not explored in any way. The movie's tone is also inconsistent with moments of tension and horror mixed with cheesy one-liners and exaggerated action scenes.As for directing by Ben Wheatley, it's competent but not remarkable. The film's score is forgettable, without any standout tracks or memorable highlights. While the cinematography's adequate, some of the effects are hit or miss. Some of the sea creatures are pretty impressive, while others seem like they were taken out of a low-budget film.The editing feels a bit disjointed with certain scenes appearing rushed and others overly prolonged. The movie's pacing is uneven with moments of action followed by extended periods of explanation. And the dialogue is utterly forgettable with zero standout lines or memorable moments.The Trench is a monster movie that essentially matches the original. Although there are moments of suspense and excitement, the film falls short due to its storyline, shallow characters, and inconsistent tone. If you're a fan of the first film you might find this sequel enjoyable. But if you're seeking a substantial cinematic experience, it may leave you disappointed.

title: Bigger, fun and full of chum.
text: Jonas Taylor leads a research team on an exploratory dive into the deepest depths of the ocean. Their voyage spirals into chaos when a malevolent mining operation threatens their mission and forces them into a high-stakes battle for survival.Ben Wheatley's 'Meg 2: The Trench' is a lot of fun if you leave your brain at the door. While Wheatley delivers entertainment in spades, his offering, like its predecessor's adaptation, shares very little with the source material. It shares as much with 'The Trench' (1999) novel as the 2018 film 'MEG' did with the 1997 book 'Meg: A Novel of Deep Terror'. If you go in with questions like what happened to Jonas' ex-wife or how did Suyin die, you'll be disappointed from the outset.Cliff Curtis returns as Mac, along with Page Kennedy as DJ and little Sophia Cai as Meiying Zhang, now 14 years old. There are more extinct creatures, more megalodons, more action, with some genuinely laugh-out-loud moments from Statham, but particularly Wu Jing as Jiuming Zhang, Meiying's uncle, and from the rapport between Kennedy and Curtis.Sergio Peris-Mencheta shines, oozing bad guy vibes as emotional and dangerous Montes. With little screen time, Sienna Guillory is notable. The supporting cast, right down to the disposable mercenaries, do a great job.Harry Gregson-Williams returns with a fitting score along with the pop music covers, which complement the on-screen set pieces and action sequences, including giant sharks, octopuses, and extinct Snappers. Fans of the original novel will welcome the T-Rex flashback in the opening.Adaptation niggles aside, it suffers from some of the same issues that Jon Turteltaub's bumpy toned offering did: poor pacing, some clunky dialogue, and a handful of iffy CGI shots. That said, for the most part the visual effects are impressive, especially the Snapper creatures, the trench sequences and there's some sweeping cinematography from Haris Zambarloukos. Thankfully, Wheatley keeps the colour of the water as consistent as Statham's pulse pounding action scenes and cutting one-liners.Overall, don't expect the tone of 'Jaws' or Steve Alten's novels. Wheatley seamlessly takes the helm from Turteltaub, offering a more outlandish Meg versus Statham. It's bigger, fun and full of chum. Recommended.

title: Superb action in this movie.
text: The Meg is one of those summer movies that you go to escape the heat and enjoy with a box of popcorn and a cup of soda. You have action, suspense, and some humor. Jason Statham is the diving expert who's haunted by his decision to leave his two friends to die in order to save a remnant of a submarine crew. He's now reluctantly but resolutely goes back into the ocean to save a stranded research crew which includes his ex-wife. Although he gets the job done, one crew member sacrifices himself by distracting what turns out to be the megaladon or The Meg for short. While the rescue was mostly complete, Jonas (aka Jason Statham) and the crew inadvertently allowed The Meg to come up and wreck more havoc to the southeast Asian region.

title: Another chinese propaganda film
text: I usualy enjoy Jason Statham films but not this time. For his part, he was believable and carried his character in typical Jason Statham fashion. The other characters were flat, one dimensional and may as well have been reading from the screen. The special effects were lackluster and not up to 2023 standards. Who puts a bright white border light around a screen? Like an edge light around your computer monitor right now. It would shine a light back towards you and only make looking at that screen that much more difficult/irritating. The dialogue was contrived. I was able to predict several of the quips written into the script. I won't buy the blueray/digital code because I doubt I'd ever enjoy watching it twice when the first time was boring. That and It's pure chinese propaganda and is a film that caters to china. I've no problem with a country making a film for the domestic market but by the same brush stroke, I'm not part of that domestic market so it isn't for me, even with an English speaking actor.

title: A bite that edges up a little bit in its predessecor
text: The movie starts a little bit uneven, but it elevates it on other things. Its a little derivative. It covers everything with the performances of the cast to bad the descision that they made with the cast from the first film are somehow a let down. Loving that they give us an action packed trailer but it is more overstuffed bonanza when you watch it. They decided to create a villian that is seemingly mance but truly forgettable. They changed the settings a little bit, not just dwelling in the ocean but created some beasts that can be incorporated in different environment. An enjoyable movie that elevates a little to nothing in its predecessor makes it a watchable summer movie.

title: Just lean back and enjoy the ride...
text: Well, I really enjoyed the 2018 movie "The Meg", but then again I also really enjoy movies with killer sharks. And I had definitely been looking forward to watching the 2023 sequel "Meg 2: The Trench".Writers Jon Hoeber, Erich Hoeber and Dean Georgaris put together a storyline and script that was a worthy enough follow-up to the 2018 movie. Sure, "Meg 2: The Trench" was by no means rocket science, nor was it a movie that challenges the intellect of the audience in any way. Nay, "Meg 2: The Trench" is pure and simply a popcorn movie; you lean back in the seat, munch the popcorn and enjoy the action on the screen without adding realism to the movie experience.The movie has a good cast ensemble, with taking into consideration the premise of the type of movie that it is. With Jason Statham in the leading role, you sort of know what kind of movie you're getting into; and he does deliver exactly that, for better or worse. It was also nice to see the likes of Cliff Curtis and Jing Wu in the movie. Actually, the entire cast ensemble put on good performances. Sure, you're not in for an evening of Shakespearian theater here, but you get what you would expect from a movie such as "Meg 2: The Trench".Visually then "Meg 2: The Trench" was good. The megalodons look cool and rather real, as did the other creatures. And for a movie such as this, then having proper and good special effects is a make or break thing, and luckily they had the budget for proper special effects and CGI effects, and the people working on those really came through. I was rather impressed with the visuals in the movie.I have to admit that the other creatures the writers put into the storyline was something I could have been without; the megalodons were more than enough. And truth be told, it sort of made the movie unnecessarily more cheesy and campy than it had to be with those additional added creatures. However, I did enjoy the intro of the movie with the Cretaceous period, it was actually a nice enough thing."Meg 2: The Trench" was an enjoyable and entertaining popcorn movie for sure, though it wasn't really fully as entertaining as the 2018 movie "The Meg", but it was a close contender.My rating of director Ben Wheatley's 2023 movie "Meg 2: The Trench" lands on a six out of ten stars.

title: The Obligatory Watered-down PG-13 Shark Movie of the Week
text: POSITIVES;To be honest, I quite enjoyed most of the human parts in this film more so than a majority of the monster segments, which I found a good bulk of those scenes to be downright dull (this is problematic). When the least interesting aspect of your creature feature are the creature elements, that's how you know you've royally messed up. Frankly, when there were dramatic scenes involving the underwater industrial espionage, it all felt rather thrilling at points. Astonishingly, this is when it was able to keep my attention and managed to be somewhat cool, particularly when they were traversing the deepest depths of the ocean floor (fairly intense stuff). I didn't get deeply engaged in that side of the story, but it was more tolerable than the slog-fest of monster-action sequences that were (unfortunately) about to ensue. I liked the gorgeous macaw that those bad guys had aboard their cargo ship in the beginning of the film (that was a pleasant surprise). As shallow as this comes off sounding (bad pun intended), it was real nice to once again see that at least some eye-candy for the male-gaze was thrown into the third act, even if it was only for a few brief shots (that upside was very much appreciated). And finally, it's always a treat seeing everyone's favourite gruff macho Cockney (Jason Statham) be the leading man in another action role. There's all the praise this movie is getting from me (I was really reaching to find these good points).NEGATIVES;I know that a lot of big, bombastic, action-oriented Hollywood flicks nowadays are badly put together with their choppy editing, but jeez Louise... were they taking the Mickey, or what?! I swear, it really felt like the cinematographer was hopped up on about 50 cans of red bull and the editors had ADHD, because you genuinely can't tell what's happening onscreen during any of the action scenes involving the sea creatures (call that hyperbole if you want, but it's an apt description). Did they think this was supposed to be on the same level of insanity as Statham's high-octane Crank movies, or what? Plus, they must've edited these scenes with a weed-whacking garden strimmer (then piled them all into a blender, just for good measure). There are so many quick cuts with fast edits in these kinds of moments, it all leaves you feeling nauseated, to a certain extent (the camera operator seriously needed to calm the heck down and chill out). I'm not ashamed to admit that whenever the effects-heavy action scenes just started to amp up to headache-inducing levels, I truly had to close my eyes for the duration of these manic sequences, especially the climax when a giant octopus rocks up at a holiday resort (as seen in the trailers, so it's not a spoiler). I didn't do this out of fearing seeing blood/gore (of which there was none), but because those hectic scenes were literally unwatchable (no joke). The action scenes in the original movie were adequately well-made compared to this flounder of a follow up.CONCLUSION;If you're super into cheesy monster B-movies that're nothing but fun popcorn entertainment, this'll (probably, maybe) leave you feeling nauseated and give you a headache as a result of watching its incomprehensible creature chaos. If you're someone who's a fan of quasi-serious spy-esque espionage thrillers (sort of accommodating a James Bond vibe), then I'll bet all the absurdly goofy monster nonsense is just going to put you off seeing this entirely. So ultimately, what you basically have is a commercialised big-budget summer movie that's made for no one because it doesn't know what audience it's trying to appease/appeal to. Like the old saying goes; "if you try way too hard to please everyone, then you'll end up pleasing no one at all." Even people that were perfectly satisfied with the first one will most likely be disappointed by this muddled sequel and won't enjoy it as much (this actually made me miss the first Meg).

title: Unadulterated drivel !!!
text: What I don't get is with this many bad reviews how does this movie make 320 million (as of yet). Good publicity or gullible audience, take your pick. The movie was dry and acting terrible. These days with Hollywood's over dependance on CGI, content and acting has taken a back seat. The story starts and all of a sudden I am in the middle of it already. Why waste time even building up the plot. Jason S should be more selective with his projects or he is going to use up his hard earned goodwill and end up doing B movies like some of his contemporaries. Jaws was so impressive back in the days, this is just a cheap caricature not worth the time of your life. Instead watch a re run episode of Breaking Bad or some other tv series.

title: A rare miss for Statham
text: Kenny's Movie Review"The Meg 2: The Trench" (2023)Now in theatersA research team encounters multiple threats while exploring the depths of the ocean, including a malevolent mining operation.First off a couple things, huge Jason Statham fan and heck even liked "Parker" with J-Lo, so I'm a little biased towards his films, secondly I loved the first film a lot "The Meg" was a good action film but I did learn something from the first one.Which leads me to this one? i understand why people may not like this film, but i genuinely loved it. My favourite guilty place is shark movies, and this one has to be on par as my favourite. It has a refreshing mixture between shark action, plot and development. The whole film isn't the usual "stranded and surrounded by sharks" and it adds texture through the change in sets and (predictable but well foreshadowed) twist(s). title: If your stupid you will like it.
text:
The Director needs a slap, he had megs, Jason Statham and a good budget and somehow failed at both action and plot.The action is adequate the comedy is cringe and pointless and the plot is beyond a joke. This is a film for idiots who will say it looked cool, as to be fair, it did at times but for anyone who wants a bit of context to their chaos it fails unlike the first that at least gave us some.The villains for me are the worst in this they have no real explanation to their motives or background apart from a small hint at awareness to protecting the climate. Jason Stathams lot are trying to protect the eco system and the villains are looking to make gains from it...
But we don't get anything more or how the villains managed to infiltrate the good guys operation..
The ending is so poor again no real explanation to anything that led up to the films climax. The Director for me really let off a stinker with this he traded a few cool action shots at the expense of any real attempt to go more in depth of a narrative that could have been really interesting.

title: Who Cannot Love A Plastic Shark
text: Meg 2 The TrenchThis was a script that stretched credulity to the limits, we find when exploring one of the deepest trenches in the world only to discover a crowded illegal mining operation populated by baddies.The shark appeared much more in the latter half of the movie, Jason Statham played himself and we had a whole array of situations where our hero came good.We should not be overly critical of a movie entirely built on a nautical dinosaur from the Jurassic age, as this elemental alone is the reason for the movie. I thought it was very entertaining throughout, of course instantly forgettable, but the inclusion of Tiffin, from Meg 1, the clipped Yorkie was the glac√© cherry on topI'm giving this a firm 6 outta 10 for entertainment value alone.

title: Megadisappointment.
text: The trailer for "Meg 2: The Trench" makes it look really good. That's because it shows the best stuff, and the special effects looked better on my phone, than on the big screen!"The Meg" was a fun, exciting GIANT PREHISTORIC SHARK movie. This "sequel-just-so-we-can-say-we-made-a-sequel" wastes too much time focusing on half-baked nonsense about bad guys engaged in illegal mining 'way at the bottom of the trench where the Megs live. It's never explained who they are or what exactly their game is, but It doesn't matter anyway, because we don't care about them -- we wanna see GIANT PREHISTORIC SHARKS!"The Trench" is peopled with cookie cutter characters whose interpersonal relationships are simply not convincing. The fatherly role Jonas (Jason Statham) plays to Meiying (Sophia Cai) is potentially appealing, but the cast, and the plot are so diluted with extraneous characters and stories that their relationship is never developed beyond standard father-daughter sitcom banter. Presumably, he had a deeper relationship with the lady scientist that he was friendly with in the first film, but nothing is said about that except that she's dead now, and he's apparently guardian of her daughter. Oh, and Meiying's annoying uncle (Jing Wu) is in the picture now.Most of the Megalodon action is saved for the latter part of the movie, when everything goes nuts and other prehistoric sea creatures emerge to help perpetuate the ridiculousness. The comedy kicks into high gear at this point, too, probably in an attempt to lighten things up in the midst of the death and destruction, but it just adds more ridiculousness.Now, there's good-ridiculous, and there's bad-ridiculous. "The Meg" was good-ridiculous; "Meg 2" is bad-ridiculous. Save some time, just watch the trailer.

title: Just made for the Chinese market
text: Just terrible compared to the first movie, 2 out of 10 as it's got some ok action and starts Jason statham.But it's basically a chinese propaganda movie, a third of the movie is in chinese, and 95% of the cast are chinese, but even when those actors are speaking English you can't understand a word they are saying so you have to watch the entire movie with subtitles on.In this movie all the chinese characters are either hero's or rich fun loving tourists, al the villains are white westerners, so it's obvious who the market is hereEven without this, the movie is terrible, the acting and script is like an 80's straight to video movie, and the editing is so bad it's up there with highlander 2.Don't bother, just watch the Meg 1 again, or better still just watch Jaws.

title: A Bloodless Turkey
text: I don't mind big dumb popcorn films about sharks when they're done right (I like Deep Blue Sea and Piranha 3d a lot), and Jason Statham is always good value, but this was just a pile of steaming rubbish.The first hour and a half is bland and boring, though it picks up a little in the last half hour when the tone completely changes to pure silliness, becoming an Hollywood executive's idea of 'crazy'. The VFX are mediocre and the creature designs are uninspired. The script is just terrible, and most of the characters have no character. The parts that are funny are only funny because they're embarrassingly bad. You laugh at it, not with it.I assume the dialogue is as bad as it is because it's calculated to occupy the common middle ground between Chinese and American child audiences. Utterly witless, when it could have been knowingly dumb and funny.How anyone can make a film about a giant shark without any gore AT ALL beggars belief. I guess the problem is that this film has to get past the brutal censorship of the Chinese Government, and at the same time appeal to as many people as humanly possible. In that exciting artistic environment, an almost unwatchable film has been churned out.Finally, as a fan of director Ben Wheatley's Kill List, Sightseers and A Field In England, I'm saddened to see the decline of a once-exciting talent. His last decent film was High Rise 8 years ago, and since then his output has gone down the drain, culminating in this crud. What a sell out. Surely he must have read the script before he agreed to this? I can only assume his early films were special because of his collaborators.

title: An R Rated Version Would have been Better
text: In Meg 2: The Trench, there are things to be praised. But at the same time, there are a lot of things to be criticized.In the movie, I praised the performance of Statham and Peris-Mencheta, action scenes, direction, visual and sound effects, cinematography, and ending, which may set up for a sequel in the future.But what I critized in Meg 2: The Trench is the story because there is no innovation in it when we want to compare it to the first movie. Also, when the person watches this movie, they feel that it would have been better if the movie was R rated because the nature of the story its elements require that. From my point of view, the movie failed to take full advantage of its premise because of that.But these flaws won't prevent me from giving a fair score to Meg 2: The Trench because at the end, it was an enjoyable movie to watch. That is why regarding the score, I give Meg 2: The Trench 6 out of 10.

title: Average Shark Movie
text: The Meg 2 is alright, It's nothing crazy good but it's not absolutely terrible either.In terms of storyline it just went downhill from the first one. The crew is back but missing the very beautiful Li Bingbing this time as she is apparently dead now. The humans are still exploring the trench where the megs are found even though a meg followed them back through it in the first movie. Anyway outside of them not being able to leave the place alone and megs seemingly unable to follow them through it anymore they have a captive meg as well. Outside of that well it's just more greedy humans after rare earth metals.Casting wise well that also got worse since Li Bingbing is no longer in the movie being dead and all and they just added a bunch of random new people in the film. Also the acting performances where kinda bland but overall it's alright.VFX and SFX is probably the best part with the trench life and environment looking pretty cool. Though the megs just didn't feel as great as they did last movie. Also the size of the megs in the trench to when they were eating people just felt like it changed.Overall a 6/10, Felt lacking in story and the cast was okay but the effects weren't terrible and watching people get eaten is always fun so can't go wrong there especially when it's like 20 people being chowed a time.

title: A loated useless sequel
text: While the first movie was just another stupid, but enjoyablem summer blockbuster this sequel is trying to hard and missiong the mark badly.In fact the meg is pretty much an afterthought and you seen most of it if you watched the trailer. Clearly this sequel does not understand what this movie should be about. Noone cares about the bad guys here or the other boring creatures. The message about ocean preservation is totally lost in this mess as well and was unneeded.It just wants to do too much but achieves little, even Jason Statham can't save this shipwreck. Watch the first one again instead seriously.

title: FAR worse than Meg 1
text: This is a classic example of a movie that didn't need to be made, but they did it anyway because they are greedy and money hungry. Films that are made for the sole purpose of making money and not for telling a story or for art (like the fast & furious movies for example) are always going to suck, because they have no soul and even the actors who act in these cash-grab films don't act with their heart because they KNOW the movie sucks and they're just there for the paycheck. This movie is the perfect example of all of that. The movie has at least 7 plot holes from what I counted. It really is a terrible movie. It's not even a good action movie like the first one was.... this is just terrible, and should not be watched by anyone who values 2hours of their life.

title: "You don't see fish down here wearing armor"
text: The first Meg film was a dumb fun shark attack movie. I was hoping for something similar with the sequel. However, the new director here doesn't seem to understand the assignment. They instead created a fast and furious movie with a Meg.It is just mostly 90 minutes of forgettable human conflict, with some fun Meg action (and a land Dinosaur and Kraken for some reason?) near the end.The human characters are all still kind of bland but that isn't why we are watching this. It is the Megalodons and they are barely even in this. Even when they are, they are not as scary as they were in the first film.

title: Meaningless and unwatchable
text: Meg 2: The Trench returns with Cliff Curtis, Page Kennedy, and Jason Statham from the original movie along with Jing Wu who mysteriously was the son of Zhang. Zhang only had a daughter but somehow we are now introduced to a son. The storyline was less about the Meg but about treachery, jealousy and mistrust when Wu's partner betrays him by mining the depths of the oceans for the minerals. Ben Wheatley signed on to direct because he loved the first one so much. The storyline was all over the place with terrorists attacking a research rig to adding additional Megs for Jason to kill with his own hands. The CGI was on par but it just was not fun to watch, they just tried to hard. The jokes were not laughable, and overall this sequel is not worth your time, don't bother.

title: It delivered as expected...
text: I don't think anyone involved in making this movie took it seriously, however they did believe in their characters and delivered fun performances. Yeah it's silly, and that's the fun part.Statham back on point with the fight sequences, and the banter between characters seemed to demonstrate the fun they were having.Will I remember it next week? Doubt it. But then, to answer Maximus...I was entertained.The vfx were good enough to keep me in the movie. The antagonist did a great job being slimy. The Meg didn't scene steal, so I hope it got points on the backend!I will definitely vote for the dog as best supporting actor this year!! üòÇ

title: Mega 3 star Melodrama
text: Meg 2: The Trench is a sequel to the 2018 film The Meg, which starred Jason Statham as a deep-sea diver who battles a giant prehistoric shark. The sequel sees Statham return to the fray, this time facing off against even bigger and more dangerous sharks.The film has some good points. The CGI sharks are impressive, and the action sequences are well-choreographed. Statham is also good in the lead role, and he brings a lot of charisma to the film.However, the film also has some flaws. The plot is predictable and unoriginal, and the characters are one-dimensional. The film also drags in places, and it's overlong at two hours.Overall, Meg 2: The Trench is a middling sequel that doesn't quite live up to the original. It's not a bad film, but it's not a great one either. If you're a fan of the first film, you'll probably enjoy this one, but if you're not, you can probably skip it.Here are some of the specific things I liked and disliked about the film:Liked:The CGI sharks are impressive. They look realistic and believable, and they're a lot of fun to watch.The action sequences are well-choreographed. They're exciting and suspenseful, and they keep the viewer engaged.Jason Statham is good in the lead role. He brings a lot of charisma and humor to the film, and he makes the character likable and relatable.Disliked:The plot is predictable and unoriginal. It's basically the same plot as the first film, just with bigger sharks.The characters are one-dimensional. They're not very well-developed, and they're mostly just there to serve the plot.The film drags in places. It's overlong at two hours, and it could have been tightened up a bit.Overall, I would give Meg 2: The Trench a 3 out of 10. It's not a bad film, but it's not a great one either. If you're a fan of the first film, you'll probably enjoy this one, but if you're not, you can probably skip it.

title: Ultimate popcorn fun
text: With 5.6 IMDB rating, I entered the theater with low expectations. Oh boy, this movie did not disappoint. I loved the over the top action scenes and the 3D visuals are pretty amazing as well. It was fast paced action with several jump scares. Both Statham and the Chinese actor did very well. Yes it is generic and yes it has over the top giant monsters. But what else do you expect from a movie about a Giant Shark? I think the critics need to consider that some people like pure fun as well. So I do not think this movie deserves the low rating it got.This has to be the best popcorn movie of the year up until now. Do not listen to the critics. Just have fun.

title: It was alright, but was worth a watch!
text: MEG 2: The Trench was alright. It's not a bad sequel once you get used to Jason Statham, cause he's a really good actor, and the beer guy to have in every action movies his in.The first MEG movie was better because it has tones of jumpscares and also some pretty cool action sequences than the second one. The second one has some good jumpscares, but the story was way different from the first. Still has some action sequences tho, but still pretty different.Every main characters returned, but one of them didn't, because one of the characters was killed off, but I'm not gonna say or tell who it was. Because, like I said, before the story was way different from the first movie. But it was still worth a watch, because I really do love underwater, monster movies. Not bad, for a giant shark called the MEG.

title: Repetitive confusing plot
text:
The first Meg movie was very good but this one just tries to slide onto that hype and fails in doing so
The story is confusing, it is never properly established why they started diving into the trench again despite swearing in the last movie not to.Characters are killed off without any emotional tension.The movie does not seem to make a statement like anything that is happening is serious unlike the last movie which had its funny moments as well as serious climatic situations whereas this movies lacks any serious climax
Movie elements are never properly established and the action sequences and finale are something that arouse zero interest and the only reason the movie would deserve a watch is because of the acting and the cgi.

title: Monster Mash-up
text: What do you get when you borrow scenes of Jurassic Park, Jurassic World, The Abyss, Titanic and then add Evil Corporations, pollution and tons of CGI?If the 1st installment was Meg-lien this would be Meg-liens. It certainly has plenty of action, bad dialogue and paper thin characters... but who cares?It is a blast and exactly what I expected... only better. The only issue I had was it's release comes right on the heels of the recent Titan disaster and some of those scenes were really close to the mark.If you're looking for a simple popcorn movie to waste a couple of hours with then this is the ticket to just turn off your critical thinking and roll with it.

title: A boring one
text: Meg 2: The Trench, directed by Ben Wheatley, is not worth a watch but could be given a try for the experience. The story is about a bunch of scientists who outsmart Megs while facing threats from their enemies. The writing was really bland and offered the same cliched story that we have seen in many other movies similar to this. The writing was not interesting at all and did not grab interest right from the beginning. The characters were poorly written and their characterization was in a good vs. Bad form with a much more cliched and watered-down form. The screenplay was as predictable as it could get. Right from the start, we could figure out what the ending could be and the ending is worse than what the audience could expect. The conflict was familiar and the screenplay made it more predictable for the audience and has them bored throughout the movie. The direction was boring and did not make an impactful experience for the audience to watch. As the movie progressed, the direction was far left behind, leaving the plot as boring as it was. The performances were decent and were up to par, the actors acted on point as they should have. The technical aspects were great, especially the CGI. The CGI looked really good on screen and haven't looked like they were fake at all. The CGI effects have really paid off for the efforts on the screen The cinematography was great and looked realistic on screen. The color contrast looked great on screen. Overall, the movie is something you could watch if you really wish too.

title: Like a 12 year-old directed an 8-year old's script
text: Total infantilistic nonsense and crap acting. The B-movie canon that underlines typical post-00s Hollywood action blockbusters: letting 12-year-old glands direct 8-year-old scripts. Or, perhaps, Chinese production money venturing into action culture for US prime audiences based on lessons and prototypes (e.g., about buddy relationships, gender roles, environmental sensibilities etc.) derived from such reliable material as "The Expendables". Whatever the case might be, it's all over the place in every department: casting, acting, script, direction.Only slightly positive aspect, the monsters (sorry, near-extinction, protected ancient species, I meant) and battles between them (though precious few and far between). Hence, a 4*, for nice, massive, havoc-wrecking predators. At least they (i.e. Their CGI simulations) can act their part.

title: Not for the thrills, but nice watch
text: I went to the theatres with medium expectations after watching The Meg 1 the night before. With the movie promising more megalodons, I did expect more shark thrills and action, which The Meg 2 didn't satisfy. The first half of the movie mostly disregarded the sharks and focused on humans. There were a few dragging and slow-paced scenes, but there was also drama, suspense and a few scares. The second half dived more into the sharks' rampage and the actors' quest to survive and save others. However, it also brought in more creatures like mini-dinosaurs and squids in contrast to the movie's title. In the end, the film felt slightly rushed and incomplete, as many questions were left unanswered, but it was a nice watch overall.

title: Overall bad, mindless action movie
text: The Meg 2 is bad. I mean really bad. It is shamefully bad considering how much money was sank into it. I have seen worse movies but not many (if any) that had these kinds of recources.It's full of utterly ridiculous amount of action scenes, bad jokes and simple dialogue. Writers who create crap like this don't deserve higher salaries. Characters have zero substance, the basic storyline was probably made up in a day and then boosted with a solutely amazing action scenes. At least some of the actors could have offered so much more but they don't really have anything to work with here. Statham is a basic superhero who is your regular Jack of all trades - his character does absolutely everything, and ends it with a "cool" oneliner and a veey intense stare. Everyone else basically cause chaos.There is a lot of mindless action and effects aren't especially exceptional but work well enough. If that does it for you, this can effor a bit of excitement. But don't expect anything exeptional.

title: "If anyone can do this, it's you!"
text: Jason Statham is back in the sequel we probably didn't need, but the sequel we have anyway. Hard to tell who is the bigger threat to JS and crew here - the CGI monsters from the depths or the shady folks who have their own nefarious plan in action. At least, they did until Jason Statham's Jonas came on the scene. Bad news for the bad guys!This is one of those movies where special effects reign supreme and where the acting and plot is so horrifically bad it's actually fun in a big, dumb sort of way. Well, the last thirty minutes are. It's kind of a drag before that. A few things happen but not a whole lot - the filmmakers could have cut twenty or so minutes out and it would've been much better.However, I think I speak for most everyone else here when I say that we don't need a third one, thanks all the same.

title: Braindead Gen Z tripe
text: How do movies like this actually get made?Terrible CGI effects.Stupid dialogue, stupid people doing stupid things.While it is understandable this is leave your brain at the door "entertainment" the stupidity of the whole movie makes it hard to bare. A shark attack and people just laughing & joking, armed mercenaries just casually walking through a holiday resort & people looking at them as if it a "little strange", people running in all directions screaming - the same people over and over, back & forth? Just stupid like the audience it's targeted at.No idea what's going on in the world when movies like this & Barbie are what's considered "summer movies".This movie and most of the movies in the last few years reflect the level of intelligence of the upcoming generation - minimal (and that's being kind).The future for movies (& the world in general is bleak, very bleak)Lack of compelling story line, lack of engaging storytelling, wooden acting, unlikeable characters.This movie has no redeeming qualities.

title: I thought it was a HOOT
text: You don't watch this movie expecting to find high scientific believability and a super deep storyline. You watch it for the jump scares, gore and of course, the giant sharks!What struck me about the structure of the plot is that the first and second halves seemed almost like two different movies. The first half was rather dark, slow moving and borderline boring. I was afraid it wouldn't hold my attention. But the second half was bright, action-packed, and brimming with cheap thrills and cheesy comedy. I really enjoyed it, and I jumped and handful of times. And seeing it in 3D made it even more jumpier.

title: Superhit Movie
text:
Finally, it's exciting and good cheese. Did I say foolish fun?You can actually take a break and come back and still have more to see!It's for everybody in the family.Sure it's a B film, but what a Great First Class Cheesey B film it is. You will smile, laugh, cringe, wince all the good things cheesey films make you do. It's just contagious!It's a film you watch over and over again, just because.5/5 cheesey actors
10/10 took their vitamins reptiles
48 people found this helpful. A feel-good exciting cheesey masterpiece of silly and over the top action adventure served with subtle parody satire and surgical wit.A must enjoyable see thrilling parade of reptiles, bad guys and good guys.So much action nonsense goes on but it lands on its feet as a score of 10.Big Shark things with Big teeth, tentacles reaching out like skyscrapers, deep diving to a zone underneath a zone beneath the bottom of the ocean, literally 3 steps below hell,
blown up, torn up, imploding up
All with the bestest of CGI.I got to say,
Jason Statham - is an all out action actor. He's so good and so corny and so good and so corny he's can do no wrong.He cuts the cheese like no other cheese cutter.Just a lovable magnificent performance.

title: When the sequel is worse than the original.
text: This was a movie I watched on my birthday. I wasn't expecting anything out of this film. I had seen the previous one released in 2018 and was hoping this one to be even better.But I was proven wrong yet again. Hollywood lacks talented directors with "vision". Just one name: James Cameron for his work on two movies Aliens(1986) and The Abyss(1989). These two movies showcased what an tremendous imagination he had. And both the scripts were his own.Back to this one: the plot is about a research team led by Jonas Taylor(Jason Statham) who stumble upon a secret and illegal mining operation. The rest of the movie deals with tension between the two factions along with the ever present threat of the prehistoric sharks.Verdict: pure CGI fest. No real special or make-up effects. In Jaws the shark was animatronic - not here though...Perhaps if Spielberg and James Cameron had both worked on this project, who knows, it might have turned out good.

title: Shockingly bad
text: Wow.... This was shockingly bad.... The trailer made this movie look like it was going to be a lot of fun... but I have learned lately that you cannot trust trailers and to wait for some reviews to come out from people that you trust before going and seeing it in the theater.... I'm so glad I did that with this movie..It's almost like they had two different directors for the movie..... The first half of the movie was actually OK.... Not great, not bad, just OK..... but then something happened..... it's like another Director took over or something..... it tried to become a comedy..... and it failed miserably at it...Also, Not sure who wrote this movie but they should not write another2/10 - really REALLY bad.

title: Felt like d√©j√† vu, but worse...
text: The same formula, storyline's dull and predictable, ridiculous plot, lazy script writing with horrible CGI. Left stunned when the lights are on, "what the hell did I just watch", that kind of feeling. Yes, The Meg is a family movie (understandable), but I still can't fathom with some cringe moments that somehow, "too much". Thanks to the underutilised Jason Statham and Cliff Curtis who brings depth into the storyline, Meg 2 is tries too hard to get out from the B movie section with easily forgettable scenes and dialogues. More suited to be released on streaming services rather than big screen.

title: Campy fun but thin story and flat script.
text: 3 out of 5 stars.Meg 2: The Trench is a fair science fiction action film that continues on another adventure with Jonas (Jason Statham) as he and another group of explorers visit the trench. Only to discover another corporation is drilling and opened a drift to which more Megs rise up in the ocean surface and amongst other giant sea creatures.It is an entertaining sequel. It is fun. It does have its action sequences that will make this sequel worth watching. Especially making this sequel fresh by having other sea creatures like a giant octopus or dino like creatures that walk on land.The acting is a bit dull. Jason Statham delivers the action role. The rest of the cast is forgettable with there performances. The script also fall flat with its characters and story.The visual effects are also okay. The direction could be better handled with the underwater action sequence with Jonas and a group walking on the surface on the bottom of the ocean while they are being chased by the creatures. The action was confusing. Dark lighting and poorly put together. The climax is pretty entertaining as the fight is on an island with three megs and octopus and others as Jonas and his crew fight back.It tries to be a summer blockbuster. Does feel a little thin and empty compared to the first film. Still entertaining.

title: What are we missing?
text: Oh yeah, a shark. We have had a shark sighting, clandestine facilities built under water by rouge other people. Not so much shark, wow. The acting is horrible, but you give all a pass, because the writing is worse. I beg, please do not follow the shere folly of making a third one. Enough now. How you got a second one through I have no idea. Please please stop now. The world thanks you if you do. It will take a bit to get the stench of Meg 2 out of the house, but you just have to push on. Horrible film. No warning of being horrible on all levels.On a scoring scale from 1 to ten, this one rates a generous 3. Most of this score is because I got to see the ocean, which is lovely. Wow.

title: HONEST REVIEW - Meg 2 has forgotten what type of movie it's intended to be
text: Meg 2 stands for Mega failure. Writing horrible, acting mediocre at best, graphics average, but directing well let's just say it's non-present.The director Ben Wheatley has really lost grasp of what The Meg is about, it's a film about a giant shark who terrorise everything in its path. You know a film is bad when not even the stellar Jason Statham himself cannot save the film.The best way to describe this film is it has identity crisis. It begins with a Transporter type theme, then it switches to The Martian vibe before it goes full throttle on Alzheimer's disease and actually losses track of what type of film it was supposed to be.The audience loved the first one because it's a simple story about hunting a giant shark. This is a simple instinct that people can relate to. Sadly the same cannot be said about part 2 in this franchise building universe. All I pray for is if there is to be The Meg 3 then please bring back Jon Turteltaub.Verdict: watch it if you literally have nothing else to do and want some mind numbing entertainment. That plus it's always good to see Jason Statham in action. 3/10 for me.

title: Enjoy the ride / dive / swim / kill
text: Have you seen The Meg? (not required by any means). Just sharing: forget about credibility. Instead: surrender. Enjoy the ride / dive / swim / kill.Yes: you have seen it all before. Yes: Meg2 is chewing gum for the brain. Yes: it will not be up for any Oscars.Having said that: do you get what you might expect? Absolutely. An entertaining B movie, impressive visuals, and a determined Jason Statham. Oh: and little time to even consider all the plot holes.I encourage you to appreciate the fun factor of Meg2 and the impressive CGI. Now available on streaming services. Wrap yourself up, ask no further questions, have yourself entertained.

title: Best Hollywood movie the trench‚ù§üòç
text: Never seen the first film, so went in blind. I love ridiculously over the top, dumb action films with Jason Statham. And this did not disappoint! Some really good action moments and the giant ancient shark was really incredibly done. One of the better shark films in recent memory. You come to see Jason Statham once again take on a megalodon shark in MEG 2: THE TRENCH, and that's exactly what you get (eventually). I was hoping Ben Wheatley would bring more creativity to this absurd sequel but those coming in without any expectation other than seeing another cheesy B-level monster action movie will probably get their fill.

title: See you later, Chum.
text:
Overall: 3.67It moves at a frenetic pace throughout and struggles heavily with structure, editing, and character development but there's enough fun, entertaining creature moments and action to keep you engaged throughout. It's really not a good movie but if you are looking for action, adventure and a good ole shark movie, you'll get it and then some. The movie fails to disappoint given its many flaws because it never truly takes itself seriously, but this also leads to zero drama or real attachment to any characters or moments which makes the film unable to grip you, thrill you, or even scare you in big moments. Nevertheless, it's a fun ride and you shouldn't miss it's what you're looking for.Top Genres - Action, Adventure, Horror, Sci-Fi, Thriller
